metadata.title: De cultu imaginum
metadata.author: Jonas of Orléans
known_issues: The phrase 'unde formatur Ecclesia' at the end of chunk 316 is somewhat unclear in its connection to the preceding text about reeds striking Christ's head.
Some passages appear to be responding to arguments not fully quoted, making the logical flow occasionally unclear

Several instances of 'Baptistum', 'Baptisti', 'Baptistatis', and 'battesimo/battesimato' appear to be corruptions of 'Baptismum', 'Baptismatis', and 'baptismo/baptismato' (baptism). These have been translated as 'baptism' throughout.
Multiple instances of Italian phrases ('L'articolo è', 'Sant'Agostino', 'Oggetto') appearing in what is supposed to be Latin text - these may be editorial notes from a printed edition
The distinction between different types of 'worship' (latria, dulia, veneration) is theologically complex and may be difficult to render consistently in English
Heavy use of rhetorical questions and digressions typical of Carolingian polemic style
The text transitions between direct quotation, paraphrase, and commentary without always clear markers
Some grammatical corrections are noted in-text ('Ut ponere debueras...') indicating awareness of grammatical issues
This appears to be the conclusion of Book 1 of Jonas's work, with the author promising to continue refuting Claudius in a subsequent book.
Some biblical citations were unclear in the original
The text breaks off mid-sentence at the end, suggesting the source is incomplete
References to 'your work' and 'Claudius' suggest this is a polemical response rather than a standalone treatise
The word 'Ciao' in chunk 370 appears to be a corruption, possibly of 'Hi' or 'Ii' (those). Translated contextually as 'For those'.
Source text has inconsistent Latin orthography and medieval abbreviations
Jonas's quotations of Claudius of Turin's work are sometimes paraphrased rather than verbatim
Several long quotations from Church Fathers (Augustine, Jerome, Chrysostom, etc.) make attribution occasionally ambiguous

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Work and Its Dedication to King Charles
chunks.latin: De cultu imaginum (Jonas Aurelianus), JP Migne
chunks.english: On the Veneration of Images, a work by Jonas of Orléans, edited by Jacques-Paul Migne
chunks.notes: This identifies the work and its modern editor

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: PRIMO LIBERO. JONAE PRAEFATIO In sequens opusculum Carolo regi porrectum.
chunks.english: Book One. The Preface of Jonas to the following work presented to King Charles.
chunks.notes: Jonas addresses Charles the Bald, son of Emperor Louis the Pious

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dilecto Carolo, inclyto regi, Jonas, minimus famulorum Christi famulus, geminam optat salutem.
chunks.english: To beloved Charles, illustrious king, Jonas, the least servant among the servants of Christ, wishes twofold salvation.
chunks.notes: Standard Carolingian epistolary greeting

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantus dominus noster gloriosissimus genitor vester, Deo dilectissimus, Ludovicus Caesar religiosissimus, in fidei sinceritate totius bonitatis virtute, proborum morum claritudine, sapientiae ac sanctitatis dote, divinique amoris ac timoris fervore exstiterit, et in ecclesiasticis negotiis, Domino adminiculante, ad honorem et cultum divinum pertinentibus augmentandis et gubernandis emicuerit; quantumque imperium paternum (quia sic Deus voluit) jure aequissimo sortitus, rectissimo justitiae libramine tenuerit rexeritque, et contra hostium impetus militariter muniverit, et Ecclesiam Christi pretioso sanguine redemptam, suoque regimini divinitus commissam,
chunks.english: How great our lord, your most glorious father, most beloved of God, the most religious Emperor Louis, was in the sincerity of faith, in the power of all goodness, in the brightness of upright character, in the gift of wisdom and holiness, in the fervor of divine love and fear, and how he shone forth in advancing and governing ecclesiastical affairs pertaining to divine honor and worship with the Lord's help. How greatly, having received by most just right the paternal empire, because God so willed, he held and ruled it with the most upright balance of justice, and defended it militarily against enemy attacks, and how he nurtured the Church of Christ redeemed by precious blood and divinely committed to his rule,
chunks.notes: Louis the Pious, Charlemagne's son, died 840 AD

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: moram patris tui, videlicet pii et homonymi viri Caroli nobilissimi Augusti, imitans, imo supergrediens, disciplinis liberalium artium educaverit, et utriusque Testamenti sancti paginis atque eximiorum Patrum dictis, ad propellenda haereticorum dogmata venenata, et instruxerit et instrui fecerit, cunctis catholicae apostolicaeque fidei filiis perspicuum esse non ambigitur, quoniam revera id quod dicitur in promptu esse cernitur.
chunks.english: following the custom of your father, that is, the pious man of the same name, the most noble Augustus Charles, and even surpassing him, nurtured it in the disciplines of the liberal arts and both equipped it and caused it to be equipped with the pages of both sacred Testaments and the sayings of the exceptional Fathers, for repelling the poisonous teachings of heretics—all this is clearly evident to all the children of the catholic and apostolic faith, since indeed what is said is seen to be readily apparent.
chunks.notes: Jonas praises Louis as equal to or greater than Charlemagne in fostering theological learning

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Is namque Deo dilectissimus princeps, inter caetera bonitatis suae studia, erga divinum cultum amplificandum multiplici modo ferventia, quemdam presbyterum natione Hispanum, nomine Claudium, qui aliquid temporis in palatio suo in presbyteratus militaverat honore, cui in explanandis sanctorum Evangeliorum lectionibus quantulacunque notitia inesse videbatur, ut Italicae plebis, quae magna ex parte a sanctorum evangelistarum sensibus procul aberat, sacrae doctrinae consultum ferret, Taurinensi praesulem subrogari fecit Ecclesiae.
chunks.english: For that prince most beloved of God, among other pursuits of his goodness which burned in many ways toward amplifying divine worship, appointed as bishop of the Church of Turin a certain priest of Spanish nationality named Claudius, who had served for some time in his palace in the honor of the priesthood, and in whom there seemed to be some modest knowledge of explaining the readings of the holy Gospels, so that he might provide sacred teaching to the Italian people, who were for the most part far removed from the sense of the holy evangelists.
chunks.notes: Claudius of Turin, appointed bishop around 817 AD, is the target of this polemic

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quam pestiferum dogma et ab Ecclesiae auctoritate abhorrens in plebem sibi transfuderit commissam, libellus quem ad Theodemirum venerabilem abbatem, se, charitate imperante, corrigentem et a superstitiosa doctrina avertere volentem, scripsit, eumdem legere et nosse volentibus patenter demonstrat.
chunks.english: But what a pestilential teaching, abhorrent to the authority of the Church, he poured into the people committed to him is clearly demonstrated to those who wish to read and know it in the little book he wrote to the venerable Abbot Theodemirus, who, compelled by charity, wished to correct him and turn him away from superstitious doctrine.
chunks.notes: Theodemirus was a Spanish abbot who challenged Claudius's iconoclasm

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Memoratus denique libellus eidem domino nostro, genitori vestro, sincerissime ac religiosissime orthodoxam fidem colenti, ob defensionem sanctae matris Ecclesiae, quae ab eodem Claudio, sicut textus suarum litterarum prodit, hostiliter impugnabatur, delatus est.
chunks.english: Finally, the aforementioned little book was brought to our same lord, your father, who cultivated the orthodox faith most sincerely and religiously, for the defense of holy mother Church, which was being hostilely attacked by the same Claudius, as the text of his letters reveals.
chunks.notes: Louis the Pious commissioned responses to Claudius's iconoclastic writings

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quem licet ego nec legerim, nec viderim, quoddam tamen ex eo excerptum, eodem genitore vestro mittente, suscepi. Praecipiens et monens [ Forte, praecipiebat et monebat] memoratus Deo charus Caesar ut ad refellenda et improbanda ejusdem Claudii, quae in eodem excerpto perversissima continebantur, dicta, et in blasphemiam vituperationemque sanctae Dei Ecclesiae irreverenter
chunks.english: Although I myself neither read nor saw it, I nevertheless received a certain excerpt from it, sent by your same father. The aforementioned Caesar, dear to God, commanded and admonished me that I should by no means fail to write back, according to the slenderness of my understanding, as much as God would grant, in order to refute and disprove the sayings of the same Claudius, which were contained in that same excerpt in the most perverse manner, and which were irreverently
chunks.notes: Jonas received only an extract of Claudius's work, commissioned by Louis to refute it

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: erant jaculata, secundum tenuitatem sensus mei, quantum Deus annuisset, nullatenus rescribere omitterem. Cujus jussioni libentissime parens, prout Deus posse dedit, et facultas temporis sivit, quoddam opusculum dirigere coeperam et magna ex parte digesseram.
chunks.english: hurled into blasphemy and abuse of the holy Church of God. Most willingly obeying his command, as God gave me ability and the opportunity of time permitted, I had begun to compose a certain small work and had arranged a large part of it.
chunks.notes: Jonas began his response to Claudius during Louis the Pious's lifetime

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed audiens eumdem Claudium juxta humanam conditionem ultimum clausisse diem, ab eodem opere perficiendo stylum meum feriendum statui. Rebar enim quod illo moriente pariter ejus error nusquam comparuisset, secundum Domini sententiam dicentis: Delebo memoriam Amalec sub coelo (Es. XVII ), nihilominus memoria illius perversae doctrinae deleta fuisset in omnium virorum prudentium pectore.
chunks.english: But hearing that the same Claudius had closed his last day according to human condition, I decided my pen should cease from completing that same work. For I thought that with his death his error would likewise nowhere appear, according to the Lord's saying in the Book of Exodus, chapter seventeen: I will utterly blot out the memory of Amalek from under heaven. In the same way, the memory of that perverse teaching would have been erased from the heart of all prudent men.
chunks.notes: Claudius of Turin died around 827 AD; Jonas initially abandoned the project

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quia, ut relatione veridica didici, non modo error de quo agitur in discipulorum suorum mentibus reviviscit, quin potius, eo dicente, haeresis Ariana pullulare deprehenditur, de qua fertur quaedam monumenta librorum congessisse, et ad simplicitatem et puritatem fidei catholicae et apostolicae oppugnandum in armario episcopii sui clandestina calliditate reliquisse;
chunks.english: But because, as I learned from truthful report, not only does the error in question revive in the minds of his disciples, but rather, as he himself said, the Arian heresy is found to be sprouting forth—concerning which he is said to have assembled certain monumental books and left them by clandestine cunning in the library of his bishopric to attack the simplicity and purity of the catholic and apostolic faith—
chunks.notes: Jonas learned Claudius's disciples continued his teachings and that he left Arian writings

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: non sum ausus quin, monitu et hortatu filiorum sanctae Dei Ecclesiae, opus quod praetermiseram enucleatim discutiendum repeterem, et singulis quae supererant perverse objectis razionalibus atque piissimis antithetis ad liquidum obviarem.
chunks.english: I have not dared to refrain from taking up again, at the prompting and urging of the sons of the holy Church of God, the work I had abandoned, examining it thoroughly point by point, and meeting with clear rational and most devout arguments each of the perverse objections that remained.
chunks.notes: Jonas resumed the work after Claudius's death due to continued controversy

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod ergo pro viribus exsecutus, idem opusculum juxta imperium patris vestri, ob capacitatem mei sensus digerens, vobis offerendum merito judicavi, ut quod patri vestro imperanti reddere non quivi, id vobis et illi pariter reddam.
chunks.english: Therefore, having carried this out to the best of my ability, arranging this same small work according to your father's command and the capacity of my understanding, I have rightly judged it should be offered to you, so that what I could not deliver to your father in his commanding, I may now deliver equally to you and to him.
chunks.notes: Jonas completed the work after Louis's death in 840, dedicating it to Charles the Bald

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sufficiere namque Claudio poterat ad cumulum miseriarum suarum error quem secutus est, duorum scilicet haereticorum, Eustathii et Vigilantii.
chunks.english: For it could have been sufficient for Claudius, for the heap of his miseries, to follow the error of two heretics, namely Eustathius and Vigilantius.
chunks.notes: Eustathius of Sebaste and Vigilantius were 4th-century figures condemned for opposing veneration of relics

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed his geminis pestibus minime contentus, altiori perditionis suae barathro sese praecipitem dedit, dum infestissimi hostis sanctae Dei Ecclesiae Arii se sectatorem discipulumque et in vita et in morte exstitisse monstravit: in vita quidem, docendo et praedicando; in morte quoque, in nefandis codicibus suis eumdem errorem a se scriptum relinquendo.
chunks.english: But by no means content with these twin plagues, he cast himself headlong into a deeper abyss of his own perdition, showing himself to be a follower and disciple of Arius, that most hostile enemy of the holy Church of God, both in life and in death: in life indeed by teaching and preaching, and in death also by leaving behind that same error written by himself in his abominable books.
chunks.notes: Jonas accuses Claudius of Arianism, the heresy denying Christ's full divinity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Secta quippe ejusdem Arii, olim a sanctis Patribus damnata catholicoque mucrone sub perpetuo anathemate confossa, quae ab eodem Claudio dicitur resuscitata, necesse est ut sagacissimo quaesitu et diligentissimo scrutamine exstet inventa et in lucem praeferenda [ Forte, proferenda], et cum resuscitatore suo ab ecclesiasticis viris rursus sanctarum Scripturarum telis ferienda atque frustranda;
chunks.english: Indeed the sect of the same Arius, long ago condemned by the holy Fathers and pierced through by the catholic sword under perpetual anathema, which is said to have been resuscitated by the same Claudius, it is necessary that it be found by most keen inquiry and most diligent examination and brought forth into the light, and together with its resuscitator be struck down and thwarted again by ecclesiastical men with the weapons of the holy Scriptures,
chunks.notes: The Council of Nicaea (325 AD) condemned Arianism

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ne, quod absit, si delituerit, simplicium mentibus in processu temporis virus mortiferum propinet, et in perpetuam damnationem inducat.
chunks.english: lest, God forbid, if it should lie hidden, it administer deadly poison to the minds of the simple in the course of time and lead them into perpetual damnation.
chunks.notes: Jonas justifies his polemical work as protecting the simple faithful

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Humiliter igitur flagito clementiam serenitatis vestrae, rex prudentissime, ut si quid in eodem opusculo utilitatis inveneritis, gratanter suscipiatis, eumque habeatis et haberi faciatis, vosque legatis et vobis legi jubeatis.
chunks.english: Therefore I humbly entreat the mercy of your serenity, most prudent king, that if you find anything of usefulness in this same small work, you may graciously receive it and possess it and cause it to be possessed, and that you may read it yourself and command it to be read to you.
chunks.notes: Standard dedicatory conclusion requesting royal patronage

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Excerptum porro mihi missum ideo inter hanc praefationem et opusculum subsequens interserui, ut quisquis idem legere et scrutari voluerit, primum, rogo, hac praefatione lecta, idem excerptum legat et examet. Et tunc demum ad memoratum opusculum aut probandum aut improbandum manum mittat. Et quidquid minus responsum minusque praemissis pravis objectis contraitum repererit, suae sanioris uberiorisque intelligentiae scriptis et dictis, ob honorem et defensionem sanctae Dei Ecclesiae, suppleat.
chunks.english: Moreover, I have inserted the excerpt sent to me between this preface and the following work, so that whoever wishes to read and examine it may first, I ask, after reading this preface, read and examine that same excerpt. And only then may he set hand to the mentioned work either to approve or disapprove it. And whatever he finds less adequately answered and less fully countered to the perverse objections presented, let him supply from his sounder and more abundant understanding, in writings and sayings, for the honor and defense of the holy Church of God.
chunks.notes: Jonas explains his work's structure: preface, Claudius's excerpt, then his refutation

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Spain's Heretical History and Claudius's Background
chunks.latin: PRIMO LIBERO
chunks.english: Book One
chunks.notes: Beginning of the main work after the prefatory material

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Disertissimos viros et eloquentissimos, atque catholicae et apostolicae fidei invictissimos defensores, Hispaniam protulisse manifestum est. Quorum imitanda exempla et documenta sequenda quia in promptu habentur, et Ecclesiae amplectuntur, ab eis, Christo favente, non ab jure salubriter instruitur et fovetur Ecclesia.
chunks.english: It is evident that Spain has brought forth most eloquent and most articulate men, and most invincible defenders of the catholic and apostolic faith. Because their imitable examples and teachings to be followed are readily at hand and embraced by the Church, the Church is rightly and beneficially instructed and nurtured by them, with Christ's favor, not without justice.
chunks.notes: Jonas acknowledges Spain's orthodox theological tradition before criticizing Spanish heretics

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quoniam saepissime et haeresiarchas simplicitatem catholicae fidei perversis dogmatibus commaculare conantes, et multifariis superstitionibus auctoritati sanctae Dei Ecclesiae contraeuntes, creavit, et hactenus creare non cessat, cunctis valde fidelibus dolendum est.
chunks.english: But since Spain has very often also produced heresiarchs attempting to stain the simplicity of the catholic faith with perverse teachings and going against the authority of the holy Church of God with manifold superstitions, and has not ceased to produce them until now, all the faithful must greatly lament this.
chunks.notes: Jonas balances praise with criticism of Spanish heretical tendencies

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut igitur caeteros omittam, emersit ex eadem Hispania, tempore sanctae memoriae Caroli piissimi atque invictissimi Augusti, quidam Felix nomine, actu infelix, Urgelitanensis civitatis episcopus, qui, juncto suo sceleratissimo errori Eliphanto Toletanae urbis episcopo, secundum humanitatem non esse proprium filium Dei, sed adoptivum praedicare ausus est, et hac virulenta doctrina uterque Hispaniam magna ex parte infecit.
chunks.english: Therefore, to pass over the others, there emerged from the same Spain, in the time of Charlemagne, Augustus of holy memory, most pious and most invincible, a certain man named Felix, unhappy in deed, bishop of the city of Urgel. He, joining his most criminal error with Elipandus, bishop of the city of Toledo, dared to preach that Christ according to his humanity was not the proper Son of God but an adopted son, and with this virulent teaching both men infected a large part of Spain.
chunks.notes: Felix of Urgel and Elipandus of Toledo promoted Adoptionism, condemned at Frankfurt (794) and Aachen (799)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deinde apostolorum Christi actus imitari videri volentes, cum ipsi non apostoli Christi, sed praecones essent hostis antiqui, unusquisque separatim diversas provincias, eadem sua insana doctrina imbuendas, appetivere.
chunks.english: Then, wishing to seem to imitate the deeds of the apostles of Christ, when they themselves were not apostles of Christ but heralds of the ancient enemy, each one separately sought out different provinces to imbue with that same insane teaching of theirs.
chunks.notes: Jonas compares the heretics' missionary activity to demonic parody of apostolic preaching

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Eliphantus scilicet Asturias et Galliciam, cujus discipulos apud Astures me aliquando vidisse memini, quos et catholicorum virorum regionis illius, qui eorum vesanae doctrinae secundum sanam doctrinam rationabiliter renitebantur, relatu, perspicuitatisque meae probatu, secundum eorum actum et habitum, certissimos antichrist os esse liquido deprehendi,
chunks.english: Elipandus targeted Asturias and Galicia. I remember having once seen his disciples among the Asturians, whom, both by the report of the catholic men of that region who rationally resisted their insane teaching according to sound doctrine, and by my own clear observation of their conduct and manner, I clearly perceived to be most certain antichrists,
chunks.notes: Jonas claims firsthand knowledge of Adoptionist missionaries in northwestern Spain

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: manifeste cernens in illis illud beati Ambrosii compleri. Habitus mentis in corporis statu cernitur. Et illud cujusdam: Frons hominis propriae mentis depromit amictum. Qualis vultus erit, talia corda gerit.
chunks.english: manifestly seeing fulfilled in them that saying of blessed Ambrose: The disposition of the mind is discerned in the condition of the body. And that saying of a certain writer: The forehead of a person displays the garment of his own mind. What kind of face there is, such hearts it bears.
chunks.notes: Jonas invokes physiognomy, the belief that physical appearance reveals moral character

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus verissime et apertissime cognitis, et quia jam secundum apostolicum praeceptum, ut ab eadem sua erronea praedicatione desisterent admoniti fuerant, et tamen in eodem errore permanebant, ut haereticos devitavi.
chunks.english: Having recognized these things most truly and most openly, and because they had already been admonished according to apostolic precept to cease from their erroneous preaching, and yet they remained in the same error, I avoided them as heretics.
chunks.notes: Reference to Paul's letter to Titus, chapter three, verse ten: avoid heretics after warning them

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Porro idem Felix, cum multis apud Septimaniam eumdem haustum pestiferum propinaverit, eum tamen Galliae Germaniaeque, quantum in illo fuit, propinare voluit. Sed, divina gratia adminiculante, nullum apud Galliam Germaniamque ejus error locum invenire quivit,
chunks.english: Moreover, the same Felix, although he administered the same pestilential draught to many in Septimania, nevertheless wished to administer it to Gaul and Germany as much as was in him. But, with divine grace assisting, his error could find no place in Gaul and Germany,
chunks.notes: Septimania was the Gothic region of southern Gaul, more receptive to Spanish influence

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quoniam non solum apud Germaniam studium litterarum et amor sanctarum Scripturarum, verum etiam apud eamdem Galliam (quae sola, teste Hieronymo, monstra non habuit, sed viris semper fortibus et eloquentissimis abundavit), ejusdem memorabilis viri solertissimo studio et ferventissimo desiderio actum est
chunks.english: because not only in Germany did the study of letters and the love of the holy Scriptures flourish, but also in the same Gaul, which alone, Jerome testifies, had no monsters but always abounded in brave and most eloquent men. Through the most skillful zeal and most fervent desire of that same memorable man, it was brought about
chunks.notes: Jonas praises Frankish theological sophistication; Jerome's comment is from Against Vigilantius

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ut, Domino opem ferente, in sibi commissae Ecclesiae filiis et liberalium artium apprime disciplina et divinarum Scripturarum perfecte polleret intelligentia; quibus milites Christi, ut pote invictissimis armis muniti, ejus vesanam doctrinam propulsaverunt.
chunks.english: that, with the Lord bringing help, in the sons of the Church committed to him there flourished both excellent discipline in the liberal arts and perfect understanding of the divine Scriptures. By these things the soldiers of Christ, armed as it were with most invincible weapons, drove back his insane teaching.
chunks.notes: Reference to Charlemagne's educational reforms under Alcuin of York

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ejusdem namque principis jussu in unum coacti, adhibita etiam sanctae Romanae Ecclesiae auctoritate, eumdem Felicem damnaverunt, imo cum auctore sui erroris, Nestorio, quem imitatus est, perpetuo anatemati mancipaverunt.
chunks.english: For at the command of the same prince, gathered together, and with the authority of the holy Roman Church also applied, they condemned the same Felix, or rather consigned him to perpetual anathema together with the author of his error, Nestorius, whom he imitated.
chunks.notes: Felix was condemned at Aachen in 799; Jonas links Adoptionism to Nestorianism

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Memorato autem orthodoxo principe Carolo rebus humanis exempto, gloriosus filius ejus Ludovicus, pietate, sapientia et fortitudine, tanto non impar genitori, paternum (quia sic Deus voluit) triumphaliter sortitus est imperium.
chunks.english: But when the mentioned orthodox prince Charlemagne was removed from human affairs, his glorious son Louis, not unequal to so great a father in piety, wisdom, and fortitude, triumphantly received the paternal empire, because God so willed.
chunks.notes: Charlemagne died in 814; Louis the Pious succeeded him

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quo feliciter imperante, idem Felix in quodam discipulo suo nomine Claudio, ut pote (ut verbis beati Hieronymi utar) Euphorbus in Pythagora, renascitur: utique, etsi non ut pridem fidei catholicae regulam, ecclesiasticas tamen traditiones quam venenatis telis per eumdem discipulum suum jaculari nisus sit, breviter memorandum est.
chunks.english: While he reigned prosperously, the same Felix was reborn in a certain disciple of his named Claudius, like Euphorbus in Pythagoras, to use the words of blessed Jerome. Indeed, although he did not attack the rule of the catholic faith as he once did, it must be briefly recalled how he attempted to assail ecclesiastical traditions with poisonous weapons through this same disciple of his.
chunks.notes: Jerome used the Pythagorean reincarnation metaphor for heretical succession in Against Rufinus

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Antiquus etenim hostis, inimicus generis humani, ecclesiasticae quietis impatiens, qui non cessat lolium malitiae suae, quanto sibi divinitus permittitur, in agrum sanctae Dei Ecclesiae jugiter superserere, exagitavit memoratum Claudium quibusdam insidiarum suarum furiis, et in tantam audaciam prorumpere suasit,
chunks.english: For the ancient enemy, the adversary of the human race, impatient with ecclesiastical peace, who does not cease to sow the weeds of his malice continually in the field of the holy Church of God as much as is divinely permitted to him, stirred up the mentioned Claudius with certain furies of his snares and persuaded him to break out into such great audacity
chunks.notes: Reference to Jesus's parable of the wheat and weeds in Matthew chapter thirteen

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ut contra Ecclesiae auctoritatem nonnulla frivola et inepta scriptitarit, quae in lateribus demonstrabuntur. Reor igitur eum opinatum quod obeunte piae memoriae pio principe Carolo, adeo in Ecclesia, quam sanctis praecedentibus meritis idem inclytus filius ejus, nutu divino, regendam tuendamque suscepit, cognitionem divinarum Scripturarum labefactaverit,
chunks.english: that he wrote certain frivolous and inept things against the authority of the Church, which will be demonstrated in the margins. I therefore believe he thought that with the death of the pious prince Charlemagne of pious memory, he had so weakened the knowledge of the divine Scriptures in the Church, which his same illustrious son had undertaken to rule and protect by divine nod with holy preceding merits,
chunks.notes: Jonas suggests Claudius exploited the transition from Charlemagne to Louis

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ut eam suae vesanae doctrinae arietibus conquatere et ad sibi cedendum passim convertere posset; sed quantum hac opinioni seipsum irriserit, liquido claret. Quoniam ejusdem piissimi principis solertissimo studio, ita quotidie, Domino opitulante, ad meliora succrescit, ut omnibus sanae fidei perspicuum sit eam et in fidei sinceritate salubriter roborari, et in cognitione divinarum Scripturarum sapienter dilatari et spiritaliter fructificari.
chunks.english: that he could shake it with the battering rams of his insane teaching and convert it everywhere to yielding to him. But how much he mocked himself with this opinion is clearly evident. For through the most skillful zeal of the same most pious prince, the Church daily grows toward better things with the Lord's help, so that it is clear to all of sound faith that it is both beneficially strengthened in the sincerity of faith and wisely expanded in knowledge of the divine Scriptures and spiritually made fruitful.
chunks.notes: Jonas asserts Louis the Pious maintained Carolingian theological excellence

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae etiam ita super firmissimam petram fundata consistit, ut nec portae inferi ei praevalere (Mt. XVI), nec vis fluminum, nec flatus ventorum a suo eam fundamento possint quoquo modo amovere. Unde non inconvenienter de illa illud decantatur evangelium: Venerunt flumina, flaverunt venti, et non potuerunt eam movere, fundata enim erat supra petram (Mt. VII; Lc. VI).
chunks.english: The Church also stands founded upon the most solid rock in such a way that neither can the gates of hell prevail against it, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew chapter sixteen, nor can the force of rivers nor the blowing of winds in any way move it from its foundation. Whence not unfittingly is that gospel saying sung about it: The floods came, the winds blew, and they could not move it, for it was founded upon rock, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew chapter seven and the Gospel of Luke chapter six.
chunks.notes: Jesus's saying about building on rock from the Sermon on the Mount

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur idem charissimus Deo princeps, divinoque plenius amore succensus, et coelesti gratia adjutus eamdem Ecclesiam sibi creditam instanter erudit, armisque spiritalibus munit, et dictis et exemplis incessanter ad alta sustollit,
chunks.english: Because therefore the same prince most dear to God, more fully inflamed with divine love and aided by heavenly grace, constantly instructs the same Church entrusted to him, fortifies it with spiritual weapons, and unceasingly lifts it to higher things by words and examples,
chunks.notes: Jonas continues praising Louis the Pious's theological leadership

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: dignum est ut, sicut pater illius magistri ejusdem Claudii, adhibita sanctarum Scripturarum auctoritate, damnavit errorem, ita nihilominus iste gloriosus filius ejus, nulli pietate, sapientia et fortitudine secundus, discipuli ejusdem Felicis vesanas damnet blasphemias, divinarumque Scripturarum telis confodiat, Ecclesiamque commissam, Christo secum pugnante, ab his et hujuscemodi erroribus immunem liberam que reddat.
chunks.english: it is fitting that, just as his father condemned the error of the teacher of this same Claudius with the authority of the holy Scriptures applied, so likewise this glorious son of his, second to none in piety, wisdom, and fortitude, should condemn the insane blasphemies of the disciple of the same Felix, pierce them through with the weapons of the divine Scriptures, and render the Church entrusted to him immune and free from these and similar errors, with Christ fighting alongside him.
chunks.notes: Jonas calls for Louis to condemn Claudius as Charlemagne condemned Felix

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod quidem qualiter ejus pio sagacissimoque studio actum sit, in processu hujus operis, Deo annuente, patebit.
chunks.english: How this has been accomplished by his pious and most keen zeal will become clear in the course of this work, God willing.
chunks.notes: Jonas promises to demonstrate imperial condemnation of Claudius

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Is itaque de quo agitur, exortus ex eadem Hispania, ejusdemque Felicis discipulatui ab ineunte aetate inhaerens, per aliquod tempus in palatio memorati gloriosissimi ac serenissimi, Deoque amabilis Augusti, in officio presbyteratus militavit.
chunks.english: Therefore the one being discussed, having arisen from the same Spain and adhering to the discipleship of the same Felix from an early age, served for some time in the palace of the mentioned most glorious and most serene Augustus, beloved of God, in the office of the priesthood.
chunks.notes: Claudius served as palace chaplain before becoming bishop

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ut aliorum utilitati doctrina praedicationis evangelicae, quae illi admodum inesse videbatur consuleret, ipsius piissimi principis clementia praesul Taurinensis subrogatus est Ecclesiae.
chunks.english: But so that he might serve the benefit of others with the teaching of gospel preaching, which seemed to be considerably in him, he was appointed bishop of the Church of Turin by the clemency of the same most pious prince.
chunks.notes: Turin was an important Italian diocese in the Carolingian kingdom

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui dum super gregem sibi creditum pro viribus superintenderet, eumque praedicationis suae instantia ad amorem coelestis patriae, quantum videbatur, accendere satageret, vidit eum inter caetera quae emendatione digna gerebat, superstitiosae, imo perniciosae, imaginum adorationi, qua plurimum nonnulli illarum partium laborant, ex inolita consuetudine deditum esse.
chunks.english: While he was overseeing to the best of his ability the flock entrusted to him and eagerly striving to kindle it, as much as seemed possible, to love of the heavenly homeland by the urgency of his preaching, he saw that it was devoted, among other things worthy of correction that it practiced, to superstitious, indeed pernicious, adoration of images, with which very many in those parts are troubled, from long-established custom.
chunks.notes: Jonas acknowledges genuine problems with image veneration in northern Italy

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde immoderato et indiscreto zelo succensus, non solum picturas sanctarum rerum gestarum, quae non ad adorandum, sed solummodo (teste beato Gregorio) ad instruendas nescientium mentes, in ecclesiis suis antiquitus fieri permissae sunt, verum etiam cruces materiales, quibus ob honorem et recordationem redemptionis suae sancta consuevit uti Ecclesia, a cunctis parochiae suae basilicis dicitur delevisse, evertisse et penitus abdicasse:
chunks.english: Whence, inflamed with immoderate and indiscrete zeal, he is said to have removed, overthrown, and utterly cast out from all the churches of his diocese not only pictures of holy events, which were permitted to be made in churches from ancient times not for adoring but only, blessed Gregory testifies, for instructing the minds of the ignorant, but also material crosses, which the holy Church has been accustomed to use for the honor and remembrance of her redemption.
chunks.notes: Gregory the Great's famous defense of images as books for the illiterate in letters to Serenus

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sed quia errorem gregis sui ratione corrigere neglexit, et eorum animis scandalum generavit, et in sui detestationem eos quodammodo prorumpere coegit.
chunks.english: but because he neglected to correct the error of his flock with reason, he generated scandal in their souls and in a certain way forced them to break out in detestation of him.
chunks.notes: Jonas criticizes Claudius's method, not just his theology

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam si beati Gregorii dictis ad Serenum Massiliensem episcopum scribentis obedienter parere, nec non et apostoli Pauli salubria facta sequi, voluisset, nequaquam tam irrationabili facto se praecipitem dedisset.
chunks.english: For if he had been willing to obey obediently the words of blessed Gregory writing to Serenus, bishop of Marseilles, and also to follow the beneficial deeds of the apostle Paul, he would by no means have cast himself headlong by such an irrational deed.
chunks.notes: Serenus of Marseilles also destroyed images; Gregory rebuked him for the manner, not the principle

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut enim ex libro Actuum apostolorum (Cap. XVII) didicimus, atque Historiae tripartitae auctoritate astipulante cognoscimus, cum venisset idem beatus Paulus Athenas, et civitatem repletam idolis conspexisset, aras ab illis honoratas non destruxit, sed ratione ignorantiam redarguit, veritatis jura monstravit.
chunks.english: For as we have learned from the book of the Acts of the Apostles, chapter seventeen, and recognize with the authority of the Tripartite History supporting it, when the same blessed Paul had come to Athens and beheld the city full of idols, he did not destroy the altars honored by them, but refuted ignorance with reason and showed the rights of truth.
chunks.notes: Paul's Areopagus speech is the model Jonas proposes for pastoral correction

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicitur etiam Claudium eumdem adversus reliquias sanctorum non contemnendas (ut pote quorum mors pretiosa in conspectu Domini, eorumque sepulcra, ut a sanctis Patribus traditum est, honoranda) quaedam nefanda dogmatizasse, et usque nunc dogmatizare.
chunks.english: It is also said that the same Claudius has taught certain abominable things against the relics of the saints, which are not to be despised, since their death is precious in the sight of the Lord, as we read in Psalm one hundred fifteen, and their tombs are to be honored, as has been handed down by the holy Fathers, and that he teaches these things even now.
chunks.notes: Opposition to relic veneration was characteristic of Vigilantius, condemned by Jerome

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae licet serie litterarum suarum manifeste non indicet, ex his tamen quae innuit, et ex veridica quorumdam fidelium relatione, ita se rem habere liquido claret.
chunks.english: Although he does not indicate these things manifestly in the sequence of his letters, from what he hints at and from the truthful report of certain faithful persons, it is clearly evident that this is how matters stand.
chunks.notes: Jonas relies partly on oral testimony about Claudius's teachings

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter verisimile videtur hujus novitii sanctae Ecclesiae hostis animam ex duorum animabus priscorum compactam, atque uno corpori indeptam, Vigilantii videlicet et Eustathii, qui, ut verbis Sedulii utamur, ambo errore pares, quanquam sunt diversa secuti.
chunks.english: Wherefore it seems likely that the soul of this new enemy of the holy Church is compacted from the souls of two ancient heretics and fixed in one body, namely Vigilantius and Eustathius, who, to use the words of Sedulius, were both equal in error, although they followed different paths.
chunks.notes: Sedulius's line about heretics is adapted to link Claudius to earlier iconoclasts

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Licet enim in plurimis ab alterutro desciverint, in contemnendis tamen sanctorum martyrum reliquiis eorumque sepulcris dehonorandis, et nonnullis ecclesiasticis tradizioneibus reprehendendis, unum perversissime senserunt.
chunks.english: For although they differed from one another in very many things, yet in despising the relics of the holy martyrs and dishonoring their tombs, and in criticizing certain ecclesiastical traditions, they most perversely held one opinion.
chunks.notes: Jonas identifies the common thread linking various iconoclasts across centuries

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quorum alterius error a beato Hieronymo, sanctae Dei Ecclesiae eximio doctore, veritatisque fidelissimo assertore, et vesani erroris experientissimo exsecratore, strenue superatus; alterius vero in Gangrensi concilio perpetuo anatemate a sanctis Patribus est destructus.
chunks.english: Of these, the error of one was strenuously overcome by blessed Jerome, exceptional teacher of the holy Church of God, most faithful asserter of truth, and most experienced execrator of insane error. The error of the other was destroyed by the holy Fathers with perpetual anathema at the Council of Gangra.
chunks.notes: Jerome's Against Vigilantius and the Council of Gangra (circa 340 AD) against Eustathius

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ergo ut quicunque hujuscemodi damnatorum errores imitatur, et canonica auctoritate percellatur, et eorum perpetuo anathemati societur.
chunks.english: It is therefore necessary that whoever imitates the errors of such condemned persons be both struck down by canonical authority and joined to their perpetual anathema.
chunks.notes: Jonas applies the principle that heresy is inherited error deserving inherited condemnation

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Is quippe de quo agimus, quia non simpliciter graditur, sed a recto tramite aberrans, sanctorum Patrum terminos jactanter transgreditur, non frustra, sed quodam, ut creditur, vaticinio, Claudii sortitus est nomen.
chunks.english: Indeed the one we are discussing, because he does not walk simply but, straying from the right path, boastfully transgresses the boundaries of the holy Fathers, has obtained the name Claudius not in vain but by a certain prophecy, as is believed.
chunks.notes: Jonas engages in wordplay: Claudius from 'claudere' meaning to limp or be defective

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quoniam, quanquam magistri sui (quod qui nos regit longe faciat!) non videatur aperte sequi errorem, in eo tamen quod ecclesiasticae auctoritati claudicando contraire nititur, non immerito nomen Claudii sortitur, eorumque numero jure asciscitur de quibus Psalmista: Filii, inquit, alieni mentiti sunt mihi, filii alieni inveterati sunt, et claudicaverunt a semitis suis (Sal. XVII).
chunks.english: For although he may not seem to follow openly the error of his teacher—which may he who rules us keep far from happening—yet in that he strives, limping, to go against ecclesiastical authority, he not undeservedly obtains the name Claudius and is rightly enrolled in the number of those about whom the Psalmist says: Strange sons have lied to me, strange sons have grown old and have gone lame from their paths, as we read in Psalm seventeen.
chunks.notes: Psalm eighteen in modern numbering; Jonas exploits the name's etymology for polemic effect

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quidam sane sanctae religionis proposito venerandus, et honorate vitae imitandus, debitoque honore nominandus, Theodemirus Pater monachorum, nunc jam rebus humanis exemptus, cum jam longe lateque fama crebrescente, ab eodem Claudio talia geri et praedicari contra auctoritatem ecclesiasticam didicisset, charitatis officio ductus, et unicae gentis amore provocatus, eidem Claudio, ut ab his se quae reprensibiliter agebat et docebat compesceret, litteris charitate refertis mandari curavit.
chunks.english: A certain man, venerable in the purpose of holy religion, to be imitated for his honorable life, and to be named with due honor, Theodemirus the Father of monks, now already removed from human affairs, when he had learned by rumor spreading far and wide that such things were being done and preached against ecclesiastical authority by the same Claudius, led by the duty of charity and provoked by love of a single people, took care to have it conveyed to the same Claudius through letters filled with charity that he should restrain himself from those things he was doing and teaching reprehensibly.
chunks.notes: Theodemirus was a Spanish abbot who initiated the controversy by challenging his countryman

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille e contra, fraternae admonitionis impatiens, turbidaque indignatione permotus, non solum in illum juste se redarguentem, verum etiam in omnes sanctae catholicae et apostolicae Ecclesiae sincerissimos cultores, Galliam Germaniamque incolentes, Christoque Domino devotissime militantes, et ab imaginum superstitiosa adoratione immunis, diversarum reprehensionum ac vituperationum jacula intorsit,
chunks.english: He on the contrary, impatient with fraternal admonition and moved by turbulent indignation, hurled javelins of various reproaches and abuses not only at him who was justly rebuking him, but also at all the most sincere worshipers of the holy catholic and apostolic Church, inhabiting Gaul and Germany, serving Christ the Lord most devoutly, and free from superstitious adoration of images.
chunks.notes: Claudius's response attacked the entire Frankish church, escalating the controversy

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: eosque et idololatriae abominatione, et falsae religionis superstitione, et innumeris aliis sceleribus irretitos, sicut textus suarum litterarum demonstrat, appellare non erubuit.
chunks.english: And he did not blush to call them, as the text of his letters demonstrates, entangled in the abomination of idolatry and in the superstition of false religion and in innumerable other crimes.
chunks.notes: These are serious charges: idolatry was the paradigmatic sin in Christian thought

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde mirari satis hominem nequeo, ut qui disciplinam recte loquendi nescit, non solum docere, verum etiam alios reprehendere, et, quod his ineptius est, in reprehensionem peritorum virorum librum praesumpserit evomere.
chunks.english: Whence I cannot sufficiently marvel at the man, that he who does not know the discipline of speaking correctly should presume not only to teach but also to criticize others, and, what is more inept than these things, to vomit forth a book in criticism of learned men.
chunks.notes: Jonas begins attacking Claudius's Latin style, a standard polemical tactic

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum nisi ob ejus errorem vanissimum refellendum, et quorumdam simplicium deceptionem cavendam, videlicet ne illius pestifera doctrina eorum quoquomodo miserabilis fieret ruina, nequaquam illius imperita scripta in manibus forent sumenda.
chunks.english: But except for the purpose of refuting his most vain error and guarding against the deception of certain simple persons, namely lest his pestiferous teaching should in any way become their miserable ruin, his unskilled writings would by no means be taken in hand.
chunks.notes: Jonas justifies engaging with bad prose only for pastoral protection

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quoniam si ab his qui litteraria arte imbuti sunt vel tenuiter discutiantur, pene nihil in eis reperitur quo ars recte loquendi et scribendi non offendatur, exceptis his quae de aliorum opusculis furtim subripuit, et quibusdam subtractis atque mutatis, compilatoris usus officio, ut sua, suo inseruit operi.
chunks.english: For if they are examined even slightly by those who are imbued with literary art, almost nothing is found in them by which the art of speaking and writing correctly is not offended, except for those things which he has furtively stolen from the works of others and, with certain things removed and changed, using the office of a compiler, inserted into his own work as his own.
chunks.notes: Accusation of plagiarism compounds the charge of poor Latinity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fertur interea in suggillationem ejusdem abbatis totiusque Gallicanae Ecclesiae, tantae prolixitatis evomuisse libellum, ut magnitudine sua quinquagenis psalmis Davidicum superaverit Psalterium, de quo non nisi quoddam excerptum in manus parvitatis nostrae est perlatum, cujus hoc est exordium:
chunks.english: Meanwhile, it is reported that in mockery of the same abbot and of the entire Gallican Church, he vomited forth a book of such great prolixity that in its size it surpassed the Davidic Psalter by fifty psalms. Of this work, only a certain excerpt has been brought into the hands of my humble self, of which this is the beginning:
chunks.notes: Claudius's polemical work was evidently quite lengthy; Jonas had only an extract

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.latin: TITULUS LIBRI. Apologeticum atque Rescriptum Claudii episcopi adversus Theodemirum abbatem.
chunks.english: Title of the Book: The Apology and Response of Bishop Claudius against Abbot Theodemirus.
chunks.notes: This is Claudius's own title for his lost work

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam absurdissima et ridiculosa, quamque auribus virorum peritorum tituli istius sit fastidiosa constructio, ipsorum puerorum qui adhuc liberalibus initiantur disciplinis, facile apertaque potest probari judicio.
chunks.english: How most absurd and ridiculous, and how distasteful to the ears of learned men the construction of this title is, can be easily and openly proved by the judgment of those very boys who are still being initiated into the liberal disciplines.
chunks.notes: Jonas mocks the grammatical construction of Claudius's title

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed idcirco certae personae ejusdem tituli rusticitatem patenter non adscribimus, quia incertum habetur utrum dittatori an scriptori, vel certe exceptionri, ascribenda sit. Ad sequentia ergo, quae propria tua, o Claudi, esse non ambigimus, apostrophen facimus, et non de his quae in eodem opere tuo perverse scripsisti cum aliis, sed magis tecum manum volumus conserere.
chunks.english: But therefore we do not openly ascribe the rusticity of the same title to a certain person, because it is uncertain whether it should be attributed to the author or to the scribe or indeed to the copyist. Therefore we make a direct address to what follows, which we do not doubt is your own, O Claudius, and we wish to join battle not with others concerning those things you perversely wrote in that same work of yours, but rather with you yourself.
chunks.notes: Jonas charitably suggests scribal error may explain some problems, but prepares to attack Claudius directly

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ais namque contra memoratum Theodemirum venerabilem abbatem: Epistolam tuam, cum adjunctis super capitulis, plenam garrulitate atque stoliditate, per quemdam accepi rusticum portitorem, in quibus capitulis denuntias te turbatum, ita inquiens, eo quod rumor abierit ex Italia de me per omnes Gallias, usque ad finem Hispaniae, quasi ego sectam quamdam novam praedicaverim contra regulam fidei catholicae, quod omnino falsissimum est.
chunks.english: For you say against the mentioned venerable Abbot Theodemirus: I received your letter through a certain rustic messenger, with chapters attached, full of garrulity and stupidity. In these chapters you announce yourself disturbed, saying this, because a rumor has gone forth from Italy concerning me through all the Gauls even to the end of Spain, as if I have preached a certain new sect against the rule of the catholic faith, which is utterly most false.
chunks.notes: Jonas now begins quoting and refuting Claudius's actual text; the work breaks off mid-refutation, suggesting the manuscript is incomplete

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aut quae in honore Creatoris humanus sensus ponit excogitare; quo sensu accipi queat, non satis elucet.
chunks.english: Or what the human mind undertakes to devise in honor of the Creator—in what sense this should be understood is not sufficiently clear.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nihil autem de Deo sibi corporeum, ut videris voluisse intelligi, humanus sensus cogitando permittitur imaginari.
chunks.english: The human mind is not permitted to imagine anything corporeal about God, as you seem to want to be understood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Illud quoque satis mirari non possum, cum de omni similitudine non facienda, secundum Decalogi praeceptum, assumpseris quamdam lascivam, agilitate praecipitatus, conclusionem ejusdem praecepti, quam praetermisisti, exponere tentaveris, quae hujusmodi est: Non adorabis ea, neque coles, ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, fortis, zelotes (Es. XX), et caetera quae sequuntur.
chunks.english: I cannot sufficiently marvel at this: when discussing the precept from the Ten Commandments about not making any likeness, you rashly assumed a certain frivolous position, yet attempted to explain the conclusion of that very precept which you had omitted, which is as follows: You shall not adore them nor serve them. I am the Lord your God, mighty and jealous, as found in the book of Exodus, chapter twenty, and what follows.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Liquet igitur, ut pace tua dixerim, in eodem facto te minus perite egisse; quod enim adorationem et cultum multiplicibus et incongruentibus verbis exponere voluisti, et regulam rectae locutionis offendisti, et ad sensum quem expleri voluisti, non plene pervenisti.
chunks.english: It is clear, therefore, if I may say so with your permission, that you acted rather unskillfully in this matter. For in attempting to explain adoration and worship with multiple and inappropriate words, you both offended against the rule of correct speech and failed to fully reach the meaning you wished to express.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Debueras siquidem sanctorum Patrum in eisdem verbis explanandis expositionem, non tuam propriam sequi, quod quia facere renuisti, ut dictum est, vim proprietatemque eorumdem verborum non satis expresse declarasti.
chunks.english: You should have followed the exposition of the holy Fathers in explaining these words, not your own interpretation. Because you refused to do so, as has been said, you did not declare the force and proper meaning of these words sufficiently expressly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Alia quippe est adoratio quae non nisi soli Deo debetur, alia quae a mortalibus, humilitatis et subjectionis gratia, aeque mortalibus exhibetur.
chunks.english: For there is one kind of adoration which is owed to God alone, and another which is shown by mortals to fellow mortals for the sake of humility and deference.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rursus alius est cultus quo non nisi divinae potentiae famulandum est, et alius est qui non solum rationabilibus, verum etiam irrationabilibus creaturis juxta modum proprium impenditur.
chunks.english: Again, there is one kind of worship that must serve divine power alone, and another that is rendered not only to rational creatures but even to irrational ones according to their proper measure.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De diversitate itaque cultus habes una nobiscum beatum Augustinum in libro de Civitate Dei decimo (Cap. I) plenissime docentem:
chunks.english: Concerning the distinction of worship, you have, along with us, blessed Augustine teaching most fully in the tenth book of The City of God, chapter one:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hic est enim, inquit, divinitati, vel, si expressius dicendum, deitati debitus cultus, propter quem uno verbo significandum, quoniam mihi satis idoneum non occorrerit Latinum, Graeco (ubi necesse est) insinuo quid velim dicere.
chunks.english: He says, This is the worship owed to divinity, or, to speak more precisely, to deity. To signify this with one word, since no sufficiently suitable Latin term occurs to me, I indicate what I wish to say in Greek when necessary.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Λατρείαν quippe nostri, ubicunque sanctarum Scripturarum positum est, interpretati sunt servitutem.
chunks.english: Our translators have rendered latreia, that is to say worship, wherever it occurs in Holy Scripture as servitude.
chunks.notes: Transliterating the Greek term for audio clarity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ea servitus quae debetur hominibus, secundum quam praecepit Apostolus servis dominis suis subditos esse debere (Efes. VI), alio nomine Graece nuncupari solet.
chunks.english: But that servitude which is owed to human beings, according to which the Apostle commanded that servants should be subject to their masters in Paul's letter to the Ephesians, chapter six, is usually called by another name in Greek.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Λατρεία vero, secundum consuetudinem qua locuti sunt qui nobis divina eloquia condiderunt, aut semper, aut tam frequenter ut pene semper, ea dicitur servitus quae pertinet ad colendum Deum.
chunks.english: But latreia, according to the custom of those who composed the divine scriptures for us, always or so frequently as to be almost always used, refers to that servitude which pertains to worshiping God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Proinde si tantummodo cultus ipse dicatur, non soli Deo deberi videtur.
chunks.english: Therefore, if only the term worship itself is used, it does not seem to be owed to God alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicimur enim colere etiam homines, quos honorifica vel recordatione vel praesentia frequentamus.
chunks.english: For we are said to cultivate even human beings whom we honor frequently in memory or presence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec solum ea quibus nos religiosa humanitate subjicimus, sed quaedam etiam quae subjecta sunt nobis perhibentur coli.
chunks.english: And not only those to whom we subject ourselves with reverent humanity, but even certain things subject to us are said to be cultivated.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam ex hoc verbo, et agricolae, et coloni, et incolae dicuntur: et ipsos deos non ob aliud appellant coelicolas, nisi quod coelum colant; non utique venerando, sed abitando; tanquam coeli quosdam colonos; non sicut appellantur coloni qui conditionem debent genitali solo, propter agriculturam, sub domino possessore, sed sicut ait quidam Latini eloquii magnus auctor (Virg., Eneide l. I, v. 12): Urbs antiqua fuit, Tyrii tenuere coloni.
chunks.english: From this word come farmers, colonists, and inhabitants. The gods themselves are called heaven-dwellers not because they venerate heaven but because they inhabit it, as if they were certain colonists of heaven—not as colonists who owe a condition to their native soil for agriculture under a lord and possessor, but as a certain great author of Latin eloquence says in Virgil's Aeneid, book one, verse twelve: There was an ancient city; Tyrian colonists held it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ab incolendo enim colonos vocavit, non ab agricoltura.
chunks.english: For he called them colonists from inhabiting, not from agriculture.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc et civitates a majoribus civitatibus, velut populorum examinibus, conditae, coloniae nuncupantur; et per hoc cultum quidem non deberi nisi Deo, propria quadam ratione verbi hujus, omnino verissimum est: sed quia et aliarum rerum dicitur cultus, ideo latino uno verbo significari cultus Deo debitus non potest.
chunks.english: Hence also cities founded by greater cities, as if by swarms of peoples, are called colonies. And through this it is entirely most true, by a certain proper sense of this word, that worship is owed only to God. But because worship is also spoken of other things, therefore the worship due to God cannot be signified by one Latin word.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam et ipsa religio quamvis distintius non quemlibet, sed Dei cultum significare videatur; unde isto nomine interpretati sunt nostri eam quae Grecia θρησκεία dicitur; tamen quia latino loquendi consuetudine, non imperitorum, verum etiam doctissimorum, et cognationibus humanis atque affinitatibus, et quibuslibet necessitudinibus dicitur exhibenda religio, non eo vocabulo vitatur ambiguum, cum de cultu Divinitatis vertitur quaestio, ut fidenter dicere valeamus religionem non esse nisi cultum Dei; quoniam videtur hoc verbum a significanda observantia propinquitatis humanae insolenter auferri.
chunks.english: For religion itself, though more distinctly seeming to signify not just any worship but the worship of God—whence our translators rendered it for what in Greek is called threskeia—nevertheless, because according to Latin speaking custom, not only of the unlearned but even of the most learned, religion is said to be shown in human kinships and connections and any obligations, the ambiguity is not avoided by that term when the question turns on the worship of divinity, so that we might confidently say that religion is nothing but the worship of God, since this word seems to be improperly taken away from signifying observance of human kinship.
chunks.notes: Transliterating Greek term for audio clarity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pietas quoque proprie Dei cultus intelligi solet, quam Graeci εὐσεβείαν vocant.
chunks.english: Piety also is properly understood as the worship of God, which the Greeks call eusebeia.
chunks.notes: Transliterating Greek

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec tamen et erga parentes officiose haberi dicitur.
chunks.english: Yet this is also said to be dutifully shown toward parents.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: More autem vulgi hoc nomen etiam in operibus misericordiae frequentatur: quod ideo arbitror evenisse, quia haec fieri praecipue mandat Deus, eaque sibi, vel pro sacrificiis, vel prae sacrificiis placere testatur.
chunks.english: Moreover, in popular usage this name is also frequently employed for works of mercy. I believe this happened because God especially commands these to be done and testifies that they please him either as sacrifices or more than sacrifices.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex qua loquendi consuetudine factum est ut et Deus ipse dicatur pius: quem sane Graeci nullo suo sermonis usu εὐσεβεῖν vocant, quamvis εὐσεβείαν pro misericordia illorum etiam vulgus usurpet.
chunks.english: From this speaking custom it came about that God himself is called pious, though the Greeks by no usage of their language call him eusebein, although even their common people use eusebeia for mercy.
chunks.notes: Transliterating Greek terms

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde in quibusdam Scripturarum locis, ut distintio certior appareret, non εὐσεβείαν, quod ex bono cultu, sed θεοσεβείαν, quod ex Dei cultu compositum risonat, dicere maluerunt.
chunks.english: Whence in certain places of Scripture, so that a more certain distinction might appear, they preferred to say not eusebeia, which sounds as if from good worship, but theosebeia, which sounds as if composed from the worship of God.
chunks.notes: Transliterating Greek terms

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Utrumvis autem horum nos uno verbo enuntiare non possumus.
chunks.english: But we cannot express either of these with one word.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae itaque λατρεία Graece nuncupatur, et Latine interpretatur servitus; sed ea qua colimus Deum, vel quae θρησκεία Grecia, latino autem religio dicitur; sed ea quae nobis est erga Deum vel quam illi εὐσεβείαν, nos vero non uno verbo exprimere, sed Dei cultum possumus appellare: hanc ei tantum Deo deberi dicimus, qui verus est Deus, facitque suos cultores deos.
chunks.english: Therefore, what in Greek is called latreia and is translated in Latin as servitude—but that by which we worship God—or what in Greek is threskeia and in Latin is called religion—but that which we have toward God—or what they call eusebeia, which we cannot express in one word but can call the worship of God: this we say is owed only to that God who is the true God and makes his worshipers gods.
chunks.notes: Transliterating Greek terms

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quicunque igitur sunt in coelestibus habitationibus immortales et beati, si nos non amant nec beatos esse nos volunt, colendi utique non sunt.
chunks.english: Therefore, whoever are immortal and blessed in the heavenly dwellings, if they do not love us nor wish us to be blessed, certainly are not to be worshiped.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si autem amant et beatos volunt, profecto inde volunt, unde et ipsi sunt.
chunks.english: But if they love us and wish us blessed, they certainly wish it from that source from which they themselves are blessed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Satis igitur abundeque sufficiunt lectoris prudentiae de diversitate cultus haec quae a beato Augustino dicta protulimus.
chunks.english: Therefore, these words of blessed Augustine which we have brought forward sufficiently and abundantly supply the prudent reader concerning the distinction of worship.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Porro de adoratione quae mortalibus humilitatis et subjectionis gratia aeque mortalibus exhibetur, multa in divinis eloquiis exempla reperiuntur, e quibus illud est in libro Geneseos: Surrexit, inquit, Abraham et adoravit populum terrae, filios videlicet Heth (Gen. XXIII).
chunks.english: Moreover, concerning the adoration which mortals show to fellow mortals for the sake of humility and submission, many examples are found in the divine scriptures. Among these is what is in the book of Genesis: Abraham arose and adored the people of the land, namely the sons of Heth, as found in Genesis, chapter twenty-three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et alibi in eodem libro: Cumque adorassent Joseph fratres sui, et cognovisset eos, quasi ad alienos durius loquebatur.
chunks.english: And elsewhere in the same book: When his brothers had adored Joseph, and he recognized them, he spoke harshly to them as if to strangers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et paulo post: Igitur ingressus est Joseph in domum suam, attuleruntque ei munera, tenentes in manibus, et adoraverunt proni in terram (Gen. XXIV).
chunks.english: And shortly after: Therefore Joseph entered his house, and they brought him gifts, holding them in their hands, and they adored him prostrate upon the ground, as found in Genesis, chapter twenty-four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et in libro Melachim: Inclinavit, inquit, se Bethsabee, et adoravit regem (III Reg. I).
chunks.english: And in the book of Kings: Bathsheba bowed and adored the king, as found in the third book of Kings, chapter one.
chunks.notes: Using Kings instead of Melachim for clarity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et paulo post: Nuntiaveruntque regi, dicentes: Adest Nathan propheta; cumque intrasset ante conspectum regis, et adorasset eum pronus in terram, dixit Nathan regi ea quae ibi sequuntur.
chunks.english: And shortly after: They announced to the king, saying, Nathan the prophet is present. And when he had entered before the presence of the king and adored him prostrate upon the ground, Nathan said to the king those things which follow there.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec paucis dicta sint.
chunks.english: Let these few things be said.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caeterum cui cordi fuerit divinarum Scripturarum paginas diligenter legere, hujusmodi adorationis uberiora potest perfacile testimonianze reperire.
chunks.english: However, anyone who has it at heart to read the pages of divine Scripture diligently can very easily find more abundant testimonies of this kind of adoration.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De adrazione vero quae soli Deo debetur, multa et innumera in utroque Testamento exstant salutifera documenta.
chunks.english: But concerning the adoration which is owed to God alone, many and innumerable saving teachings exist in both Testaments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae cum plurima et innumera sint, adeo ut non facile etiam ab ipsis peritissimis et eloquentissimis viris explicari queant, restat ut expositiones eorum quae a sanctis Patribus sancto Spiritu afflatis digestae sunt et ad nostram notitiam perlatae, paucas de multis, brevitati studentes, huic operi subnectamus.
chunks.english: Since these are very numerous and innumerable, to such an extent that they cannot easily be explained even by the most skilled and eloquent men, it remains for us to append to this work, striving for brevity, a few of the many expositions which have been arranged by the holy Fathers inspired by the Holy Spirit and brought to our knowledge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit utique Origenes in Expositione Epistolae ad Romanos (Lib. I): "Cum possent, inquit, homines Deum agnoscere, ab ejus cultu declinantes, ad imagines hominum adorandas et animalium se diverterunt.
chunks.english: Origen writes in his Exposition of the Letter to the Romans, book one: Though human beings could recognize God, turning away from his worship, they diverted themselves to adoring images of humans and animals.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut enim breviter et omnia in unum collecta definitione dicamus, adorare alium praeter Patrem, et Filium, et Spiritum sanctum, impietatis est crimen.
chunks.english: For, to speak briefly and in one comprehensive definition, to adore another besides the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, is a crime of impiety.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Idem item in eodem opere: Ego sic arbitror accipiendum quod, verbi causa, si quis in quolibet metallo, aurei, vel argentei, vel ligni, vel lapidis, facit speciem quadrupedis alicujus, vel serpentis, vel avis, et statuam illam, non idolum, sed similitudinem fecit, vel etiam si picturas ad hoc ipsum statuat, nihilominus similitudinem fecisse dicendus est.
chunks.english: The same author likewise in the same work: I believe it should be understood this way: if anyone makes in any metal, whether gold or silver or wood or stone, the form of some four-footed beast, or serpent, or bird, and sets up that statue, he has made not an idol but a likeness. Or even if he sets up paintings for this same purpose, he should nonetheless be said to have made a likeness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: in coelo; addit autem et dicit: Non adorabis ea, neque coles (Es. XX).
chunks.english: In heaven. But he adds and says: You shall not adore them nor serve them, as found in Exodus, chapter twenty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliud est colere, aliud adorare.
chunks.english: It is one thing to serve, another to adore.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Potest quis interdum et invitus adorare, sicut nonnulli regibus adulantes, cum eos in hujusmodi studia deditos viderint, adorare se simulant idola, cum in corde ipsorum certum sit quia nihil sit idolum.
chunks.english: Someone can sometimes even unwillingly adore, just as some people flattering kings, when they have seen them devoted to such pursuits, pretend to adore idols, though it is certain in their hearts that the idol is nothing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Colere vero est toto hic affectu et studio mancipari.
chunks.english: But to serve is to be enslaved with complete affection and zeal.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Utrumque ergo resecat sermo divinus, ut neque affectu colas, neque specie adora.
chunks.english: Therefore the divine word cuts away both, so that you neither serve with affection nor adore in appearance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hieronymus in expositione Danielis prophetae: Notum tibi sit, inquit, rex, quia deos tuos non colimus, et statuam auream quam erexisti, non adoramus (Dan. III).
chunks.english: Jerome in his exposition of the prophet Daniel: Let it be known to you, O king, that we do not serve your gods, and we do not adore the golden statue which you have erected, as found in Daniel, chapter three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sive statuam, ut Symmachus, sive imaginem auream, ut caeteri transtulerunt, voluerimus legere, cultores Dei eam adorare non debent.
chunks.english: Whether we wish to read statue, as Symmachus translated, or golden image, as the others translated, worshipers of God should not adore it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ergo judices et principes saeculi, qui imperatorum statuas adorant et imagines, hoc se facere intelligant quod tres pueri facere nolentes placuerunt Deo.
chunks.english: Therefore judges and princes of this world, who adore the statues and images of emperors, should understand that they do what the three youths pleased God by refusing to do.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et notanda proprietas: deos coli, imaginem adorari dicunt, quod utrumque servis Dei non convenit.
chunks.english: And note the distinction: they say gods are served, an image is adored—neither of which befits the servants of God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Oggetto idem in Expositione Ezechielis prophetae: Et septuaginta viri de senioribus domus Israel, et Jezonias filius Saphan, stabat in medio eorum stantium ante picturas, et unusquisque habebat thuribulum in manu sua, et vapor nebulae de thure consurgebat (Ez. VIII).
chunks.english: The same author in his Exposition of the prophet Ezekiel: And seventy men of the elders of the house of Israel, and Jaazaniah the son of Shaphan, stood in the midst of those standing before the paintings, and each one had a censer in his hand, and the vapor of a cloud from incense was rising, as found in Ezekiel, chapter eight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quando dicit septuaginta viros fuisse de senioribus domus Israel, qui tenerent thuribula manibus, ostendit multos alios fuisse presbyteros qui hoc non faciebant, sed forsitan peccatis aliis tenebantur: unumque nomine Jezoniam filium Saphan stetisse in medio eorum quasi principem sceleris atque sacrilegii eorum qui, omissa religione Dei, colebant idola, et in templo non adorabant Deum, cujus erat et templum, sed picturas parietum.
chunks.english: When it says there were seventy men from the elders of the house of Israel who held censers in their hands, it shows that there were many other priests who did not do this but were perhaps held by other sins. And one man named Jaazaniah son of Shaphan stood in their midst as a leader of the crime and sacrilege of those who, abandoning the religion of God, worshiped idols and in the temple did not adore God, whose the temple was, but the paintings on the walls.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sant'Agostino in libro septimo de Civitate Dei: Unum verum Deum, id est omnis animae corporisque creatorem, colere quisque contendat.
chunks.english: Saint Augustine in the seventh book of The City of God: Let each one strive to worship the one true God, that is, the creator of every soul and body.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non ideo peccat quia non est colendus quem colit, sed quia colendum, non ut colendus est, colit.
chunks.english: He does not sin because the one he worships is not to be worshiped, but because he worships one who should be worshiped, but not as he should be worshiped.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui vero et rebus talibus, id est turpibus et scelestis, et non Deum verum, id est, animae corporisque factorem, sed creaturam quamvis non vitiosam colit, sive illa sit anima, sive corpus, sive anima simul et corpus, bis peccat in Deum, quod et pro ipso colit quod non est ipse, et talibus rebus colit qualibus nec ipse colendus est.
chunks.english: But whoever worships with such things, that is shameful and wicked things, and worships not the true God, that is, the maker of soul and body, but a creature however not vicious, whether it be soul or body or soul and body together, sins twice against God: both because he worships in place of him what is not him, and because he worships with such things as not even he himself should be worshiped with.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: tamen ut quibus ea deferrentur, homines haberentur, qui dicuntur colendi et venerandi; si autem multum eis additur, et adorandi: quis vero sacrificandum censuit, nisi ei quem deum aut scivit, aut putavit, aut finxit?
chunks.english: Nevertheless, so that those to whom these things were offered might be considered men who are said to be cultivated and venerated—but if much more is added to them, even adored. Yet who judged that sacrifice should be made except to one whom he knew or thought or feigned to be god?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in eodem opere, lib. X: Putaverunt quidam angelis deferendum honorem (vel adorando vel sacrificando) qui debetur Deo, et eorum sunt admonitione proibiti, jussique haec ei deferre cui uni fas esse noverunt.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in the same work, book ten: Some thought that the honor due to God should be given to angels, whether by adoration or by sacrifice, and they were forbidden by their warning and commanded to give these things to him alone to whom they knew it is right.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Imitati sunt angelos sanctos etiam sancti homines Dei. Nam Paulus et Barnabas in Lycaonia facto quodam miraculo sanitatis putati dii, eisque Lycaonii victimas immolare voluerunt, quod a se humili pietate removentes, eis in quem crederent annuntiaverunt Deum (Act. XIV, 4).
chunks.english: The holy men of God also imitated the holy angels. For Paul and Barnabas in Lycaonia, after a certain miracle of healing was performed, were thought to be gods, and the Lycaonians wanted to sacrifice victims to them. But they, removing this from themselves with humble piety, announced to them the God in whom they believed, as found in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter fourteen, verse four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca (Cap. 4): Quaecunque igitur immortalis potestas quantalibet virtute praedita, si nos diligit, sicut seipsam, ei vult esse subditos, ut beati simus, cui et ipsa subdita beata est.
chunks.english: And after a few words, chapter four: Therefore whatever immortal power, however endowed with virtue, if it loves us as itself, it wants us to be subject to him by whom we may be blessed, to whom it itself is subject and blessed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: si autem colit Deum, non vult se coli pro Deo: illi enim potius divinae sententiae suffragatur, et dilectionis viribus favet, quia scriptum est: Sacrificans diis eradicabitur, nisi soli Deo (Es. XXII).
