chunks.english: But if it worships God, it does not want to be worshiped in place of God. For it rather supports that divine sentence and favors the strength of love, because it is written: Whoever sacrifices to gods shall be rooted out, except to God alone, as found in Exodus, chapter twenty-two.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam ut alia nunc taceam quae pertinent ad religionis obsequium quo colitur Deus, sacrificium certe nullus hominum est qui audeat dicere deberi, nisi Deo soli.
chunks.english: For, to say nothing now of other things that pertain to the religious observance by which God is worshiped, there is certainly no human being who dares to say that sacrifice is owed except to God alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in eodem opere libro X (Cap. 26): Non itaque debemus metuere ne immortales et beatos uni Deo subditos non eis sacrificando offen damus.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in the same work, book ten, chapter twenty-six: We should not therefore fear lest we offend the immortals and the blessed who are subject to the one God by not sacrificing to them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod enim nonnisi uni vero Deo sancti de beri sciunt, cui et ipsi adhaerendo beati sunt, procul dubio neque per ullam significantem figuram, neque per ipsam rem quae sacramentis significatur, sibi exhiberi volunt.
chunks.english: For what the holy ones know is owed to the one true God alone, to whom they themselves are blessed by adhering, they doubtless do not want exhibited to themselves either through any signifying figure or through the thing itself which is signified by sacraments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Daemonum est haec arrogantia superborum atque miserorum, a quibus longe diversa pietas subditorum Deo.
chunks.english: This is the arrogance of demons, proud and wretched, from whom the piety of those subject to God is far different.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in eodem opere (Lib. ult. c. 10): Nos autem martyribus nostris non templa sicut diis, sed memorias sicut hominibus mortuis, quorum apud Deum vivunt spiritus, fabricamus.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in the same work, in the final book, chapter ten: But we build for our martyrs not temples as if for gods, but memorials as for dead human beings whose spirits live with God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec ibi erigimus altaria, in quibus sacrificiomus martyribus, sed uni Deo, et martyrum et nostro, sacrificium immolamus, ad quod sacrificium sicut homines Dei, qui mundum in ejus confessione vicerunt, suo loco et ordine nominantur, non tamen a sacerdote qui sacrificat invocantur; Deo quippe, non ipsis sacrificat, quamvis in memoria sacrificit eorum, quia Dei sacerdos est, non illorum.
chunks.english: Nor do we erect altars there on which we sacrifice to the martyrs, but we offer sacrifice to the one God, both of the martyrs and ours, at which sacrifice, as men of God who conquered the world in confessing him, they are named in their place and order. Yet they are not invoked by the priest who sacrifices, for he sacrifices to God, not to them, although he sacrifices in their memory, because he is a priest of God, not of them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsum verum sacrificium corpus est Christi, quod non offertur ipsis, quia hoc sunt et ipsi.
chunks.english: The true sacrifice itself is the body of Christ, which is not offered to them, because they themselves are this.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in libro Quaestionum Veteris ac Novi Testamenti: Christiani, inquit, ut pote pauperes quos stultos vocant, unum Deum colunt in mysterio, ex quo sunt omnia, nec aliquid quod ab eo conditum est venerantur.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in the book of Questions on the Old and New Testament: Christians, as poor people whom they call fools, worship one God in mystery, from whom are all things, and they venerate nothing that has been created by him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsum enim solum sufficere sibi et abundare sciunt ad salutem.
chunks.english: For they know that he alone suffices for them and abounds for salvation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem post pauca: Non ergo nobis videtur ut quod homo facit adorari debeat.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author shortly after: It does not seem to us therefore that what a human being makes should be adored.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Factor enim a factura, non factura a factor adorari judicatur.
chunks.english: For the maker is judged to be adored by the thing made, not the thing made by the maker.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in Expositione psalmi CXIII: Noli ergo addere manus hominum, ut ex eodem metallo quod fecit verus Deus, velis facere falsum deum, imo falsum hominem, quem pro vero venereris Deo, quem quisquis pro vero Deo in veram amicitiam ricettaret, insaniret: ducit enim et affectu quodam infirmo rapit infirma corda mortalium formae similitudo, et membrorum imitata compago.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in his Exposition of Psalm one hundred thirteen: Do not therefore add the hands of men, so that from the same metal which the true God made, you wish to make a false god, or rather a false man, whom you venerate as the true God. Whoever would receive him as the true God into true friendship would be insane. For the similarity of form and the imitated structure of limbs leads and with a certain weak affection seizes the weak hearts of mortals.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in eodem opere, salmo XCVI: Homines autem in sanctos attendite, qui sunt similis angelis.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in the same work, on Psalm ninety-six: But consider men as saints who are like angels.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum inveneritis hominem aliquem sanctum servum Dei, si volueritis illum colere, et adorare pro Deo, prohibet te, non vult sibi arrogare honorem Dei, non vult tibi esse pro Deo, sed tecum esse sub Deo.
chunks.english: When you have found some holy man, a servant of God, if you wish to cultivate and adore him in place of God, he forbids you. He does not want to claim for himself the honor of God. He does not want to be God to you, but to be with you under God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca: Sic et sancti angeli illius gloriam quaerunt quem diligunt, ad ejus cultum, ad ejus adorationem, ad ejus contemplationem omnes quos diligunt rapere et inflammare studente, ipsum illis annuntiant, non se, quoniam angeli sunt, et quia milites sunt, non norunt gloriam quaerere, nisi imperatoris sui.
chunks.english: And after a few words: Thus also the holy angels seek the glory of him whom they love. They strive to seize and inflame all whom they love toward his worship, toward his adoration, toward his contemplation. They announce him to them, not themselves, because they are angels and because they are soldiers who do not know how to seek glory except that of their emperor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item post pauca: Nemo dicat: Timeo ne irascatur mihi angelus, si non illum colo pro Deo meo.
chunks.english: Likewise shortly after: Let no one say, I fear lest the angel be angry with me if I do not worship him as my God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc enim tibi irascitur, quando ipsum colere volueris; bonus est enim, et Deum amat.
chunks.english: For he is angry with you when you wish to worship him, for he is good and loves God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quomodo daemones irascuntur si non colantur, sic angeli indignantur, si pro Deo colantur.
chunks.english: Just as demons are angry if they are not worshiped, so angels are indignant if they are worshiped in place of God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in epistola ad Maximum grammaticum: Scias, inquit, a Christianis catholicis quorum in vestro oppido etiam Ecclesia constituta est, nullum coli mortuorum, nihil denique adorari quod sit factum et conditum a Deo, sed unum ipsum Deum, qui fecit et condidit omnia.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in his letter to Maximus the grammarian: Know, he says, that by Catholic Christians, whose Church is also established in your town, none of the dead are worshiped, nothing is adored that has been made and created by God, but only God himself who made and created all things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in libro de vera Religione inter caetera ita dicit (Cap. 3): Ad percipiendam veritatem nihil magis impedisce quam vitam libidinibus deditam, et falsas imagines rerum sensibilium, quae nobis ab hoc sensibili mundo per corpus impressae, varias opiniones erroresque generant: nec errorem in religione esse potuisse, si anima pro Deo suo non coleret animam aut corpus, aut phantasmata sua, quae nihil sunt aliud quam de specie corporis corporeo sensu interacta figmenta.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in his book On True Religion says among other things, chapter three: Nothing impedes the perception of truth more than a life devoted to lusts and false images of sensible things, which, impressed upon us from this sensible world through the body, generate various opinions and errors. Nor could there have been error in religion if the soul did not worship in place of its God either soul or body or its phantasms, which are nothing other than fictions shaped from the appearance of body by corporeal sense.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item in eodem: Non sit nobis religio humanorum operum cultus, meliores enim sunt ipsi artifices qui talia fabricantur, quos tamen colere non debemus.
chunks.english: Likewise in the same work: Let not the worship of human works be our religion, for the craftsmen themselves who fabricate such things are better, yet we should not worship them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non sit nobis religio in phantasmatibus nostris, melius est enim qualecunque verum, quam omne quidquid pro arbitrio fingi potest: et tamen animam ipsam, quamvis anima vera sit, cum falsa imaginatur, colere non debemus.
chunks.english: Let not our religion be in our phantasms, for any truth whatever is better than anything that can be feigned at will. And yet we should not worship the soul itself, although the soul is true, when it imagines false things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Melior est vera stipula quam lux inani cogitatione pro suspicantis voluntate formata, et tamen stipulam quam sentimus et tangimus dementis est credere colendam.
chunks.english: A real straw is better than light formed by vain thought according to the will of one supposing, and yet it is madness to believe that the straw which we sense and touch should be worshiped.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in sermone evangelico de potestate data daemonibus ut abirent in porcos: Noli, inquit, inclinari angelis, ut eis sacrificandum putes, nolunt enim: quando facis, non intelligunt; dili gunt si cum eis adora quem adorant.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in a sermon on the Gospel concerning the power given to demons to go into the swine: Do not, he says, bow down to angels so as to think sacrifice should be made to them, for they do not want it. When you do so, they do not understand. They love you if you adore with them the one whom they adore.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem in libro de Quantitate animae: Homo autem quilibet alius, quanquam sapientissimus et perfectissimus, vel prorsus quaelibet anima rationis compos atque beatissima, amanda tantummodo et imitanda est, eique, pro merito et ordine, quod ei congruit deferendum, nam Dominum Deum tuum adorabis, et illi soli servies (Deut. VI).
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in his book On the Magnitude of the Soul: But any other human being, however wise and perfect, or absolutely any soul endowed with reason and most blessed, is only to be loved and imitated, and to it, according to merit and order, what befits it should be given. For you shall adore the Lord your God and serve him alone, as found in Deuteronomy, chapter six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem nel libro de vera Religione (Cap. 55): Non nobis religio corporum aethereorum atque coelestium cultus, sed ejus cujus contemplatione beati sunt.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author in his book On True Religion, chapter fifty-five: Our religion is not the worship of ethereal and heavenly bodies, but of him by whose contemplation they are blessed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Neque enim et nos videndo angelum beati sumus, sed videndo veritatem, qua etiam ipsos diligimus angelos et his congratulamur.
chunks.english: For we are not blessed by seeing an angel, but by seeing the truth by which we also love the angels themselves and rejoice with them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec videmus quod eo paratiores et nullis molestiis interpedientibus perfruuntur, sed magis eos diligimus, quoniam et nos tale aliquid sperare a communi Domino jussi sumus.
chunks.english: Nor do we see that they enjoy it more readily and unimpeded by any troubles, but we love them more because we too have been commanded to hope for such a thing from our common Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quare honoramus eos charitate, non servitute.
chunks.english: Therefore we honor them with love, not with servitude.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec eis templa [construimus], nolunt enim se sic honorari a nobis, quia nosipsos, cum boni sumus, templa summi Dei esse noverunt.
chunks.english: Nor do we build temples for them, for they do not want to be honored by us in this way, because they know that we ourselves, when we are good, are temples of the supreme God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fulgenzio, in libro de Fide ad Donatum: Quia ipse Deus sibi soli praecipiens tantummodo serviendum, seque jubens a fidelibus adorandum, prorsus interdixit ne quis audeat creaturam adorare creaturaeque servire: propterea in fine illius praecepti, de omnibus quae creavit ita loquitur: Non adorabis ea, nec servies eis.
chunks.english: Fulgentius in his book On Faith to Donatus: Because God himself, commanding that he alone should be served and ordering that he be adored by the faithful, absolutely forbade anyone to dare to adore a creature or serve a creature. Therefore at the end of that precept, concerning all things which he created, he speaks thus: You shall not adore them nor serve them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca: Vera enim religio in unius constat Dei servitio.
chunks.english: And after a few words: For true religion consists in the service of the one God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem post pauca: Si veraciter unum Deum cum Patre Filium vera fides adorat, quae sic Deo novit a creaturis omnibus serviendum, ut noverit creaturae non deberi divinae servitutis obsequium.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author shortly after: If true faith truly adores the one God with the Father, the Son, which knows that God is to be served by all creatures in such a way that it knows that the service of divine servitude is not owed to a creature.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Firmiano Lattanzio lib. II de falsa Religione: Duplici ratione, inquit, peccatur ab insipientibus.
chunks.english: Firmianus Lactantius in book two On False Religion: In a twofold manner, he says, the foolish sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Primum quod elementa, id est, Dei opera Deo praeferunt; deinde quod elementorum figuras humana specie comprehensas colunt.
chunks.english: First because they prefer the elements, that is, the works of God, to God. Then because they worship the figures of elements comprehended in human form.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item ipse: Nihil aliud adoremus, nihil colamus, nisi solius artificis parentisque nostri unicum nomen.
chunks.english: Likewise the same author: Let us adore nothing else, let us worship nothing, except the unique name of our sole maker and parent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Voce: Supra ergo, non infra est Deus, nec in ima, sed in summa potius religione quaerendus est.
chunks.english: As he says: God is therefore above, not below, and should be sought not in the lowest but rather in the highest religion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et infra: Nihil colendum est quod oculis mortalibus cernitur.
chunks.english: And below: Nothing should be worshiped that is perceived by mortal eyes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Poterant siquidem de cultu et adoratione, quae soli Deo debetur, uberiora sanctorum Patrum dicta sufficienter proferri, nisi ob prolixitatem vitandam praetermitterentur.
chunks.english: More abundant sayings of the holy Fathers concerning worship and adoration which are owed to God alone could indeed be sufficiently brought forward, except they are omitted to avoid prolixity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sequitur ex opere Claudio
chunks.english: There follows from the work of Claudius:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Dicunt isti, inquis, contra quos Ecclesiam defendendam suscepimus."
chunks.english: You say, These people say, against whom we have undertaken to defend the Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Optima et egregia gloriatio tua.
chunks.english: What excellent and outstanding boasting of yours.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Supra dixisti, magna tibi tribuendo, te sectarum et schismatum superstitionumque atque haeresum compressorem et contritorem existere; et nunc infers et contra imaginum adoratores Ecclesiam Dei defendendam te suscepisse.
chunks.english: Earlier you said, claiming great things for yourself, that you are a suppressor and crusher of sects and schisms and superstitions and heresies. And now you add that you have undertaken to defend the Church of God against adorers of images.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pluraliter scilicet eorum personam assumens, ita inquiens: "Dicunt isti contra quos Ecclesiam Dei defendendam suscepimus," et singulariter eis respondens, paulo post subjicis: "Cui respondemus."
chunks.english: Taking their person in the plural, you say thus: These people say against whom we have undertaken to defend the Church of God. And responding to them in the singular, shortly after you add: To whom we respond.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omittimus itaque hanc dictionem vitiosam tuam, quae apud grammaticos soloecismus per numeros vocatur, eamque caeteris vitiosis et incompositis tuis dictionibus sociandam relinquimus, intellectum tantummodo ejus qui vitiosus vitiose prolatus est rimantes.
chunks.english: We therefore pass over this faulty expression of yours, which among grammarians is called a solecism of number, and we leave it to be joined with your other faulty and ill-composed expressions, examining only the meaning of what has been faultily and faultily uttered.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Beato igitur Augustinus contra paganos agens, Ecclesiam Dei defendendam se suscepisse non immerito scribit, quorum infidelitatem potenter rationabiliterque redarguit, sanctamque Ecclesiam ad eorum infidelitatem refellendam ac superandam, saluberrimis monitis instruit, imo armis spiritalibus affatim munit;
chunks.english: Blessed Augustine therefore, acting against the pagans, not undeservedly writes that he undertook to defend the Church of God, whose unbelief he powerfully and reasonably refutes, and he instructs the holy Church with most salutary warnings for refuting and overcoming their unbelief—indeed, he abundantly fortifies it with spiritual weapons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: tu vero nihil tale uspiam legeris fecisse.
chunks.english: But you have nowhere read that you have done anything of the kind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde mirari non satis possum cur gloriatus fueris te Ecclesiam Dei defendendam solum suscepisse.
chunks.english: Whence I cannot sufficiently marvel why you have boasted that you alone have undertaken to defend the Church of God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed quoniam ejusdem doctoris verbis abutens, imaginum adoratores parochiae tuae tanta invectione percellendos judicasti, cultores tamen sincerissimos sanctae Dei Ecclesiae Galliam incolentes, et ab hac superstitione immunis (quos tam in praecedentibus quam in lateribus scriptis tuis falsae religionis atque superstitionis cultores vocitas), in eadem persecutione tua minime videris excepisse.
chunks.english: But since, abusing the words of that same teacher, you judged that the adorers of images in your diocese should be struck down with such invective, nevertheless you seem by no means to have excepted in this persecution of yours the most sincere worshipers of the holy Church of God dwelling in Gaul and immune from this superstition—whom you call in both your preceding and subsequent writings worshipers of false religion and superstition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Illud quod imaginum adoratores, tibi, ad suum errorem muniendum, respondisse scripsisti, ita inquiens:
chunks.english: What you wrote that the adorers of images responded to you to fortify their error, saying thus:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Non putamus imagini quam adoramus aliquid inesse divinum, sed tantummodo pro honore, cujus effigies est, tali eam veneratione adoramus."
chunks.english: We do not think that anything divine is present in the image which we adore, but we adore it with such veneration only for the honor of the one whose likeness it is.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Una autem reprehendimus ac detestamur, quia cum eorum scientiam non subterfugit imaginibus nil inesse divini, majori digni sunt invectione, eo quod debitum honorem Divinitati impenderint infirmo et egeno simulacro.
chunks.english: We, however, reprove and detest this because, since it does not escape their knowledge that nothing divine is present in images, they are worthy of greater invective in that they have rendered the honor due to divinity to a weak and needy idol.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantumque hujusce erroris sectatores ac defensores a vera esorbitante religione, non opus est per singula mea declarare narratione.
chunks.english: How much the followers and defenders of this error deviate from true religion, it is not necessary for me to declare through individual narration.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Idipsum etiam nonnulli Orientalium, qui eodem sceleratissimo mancipantur errori, se objurgantibus respondere solent.
chunks.english: Some Easterners also, who are enslaved to the same most wicked error, are accustomed to respond the same thing to those reproving them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tribuat Dominus sua gratuita pietate ut tandem aliquando et isti et illi ab eadem eruantur superstitione, et apostolicis disciplinis salubriter instructi, traditioni revocentur ecclesiasticae.
chunks.english: May the Lord grant by his free mercy that at last both these and those may be rescued from this superstition, and, salutarily instructed in apostolic disciplines, be recalled to ecclesiastical tradition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: illud autem quod adnectis:
chunks.english: But what you add:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Quia si sanctorum immagina in daemonum cultum venerantur, non idola reliquerunt, sed nomina mutaverunt."
chunks.english: Because if they venerate images of the saints in the worship of demons, they have not abandoned idols but have changed the names.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et continuo subjungis: "Si scribas in pariete, vel pingas immagina Petri et Pauli, Jovis et Saturni, sive Mercurii, nec isti sunt dii, nec illi apostoli; nec isti, nec illi homines, ac per hoc nomen mutatur, error tamen et tunc et nunc idem ipse permanet sempre."
chunks.english: And immediately you add: If you write on a wall or paint images of Peter and Paul, Jupiter and Saturn, or Mercury, neither are these gods nor those apostles; neither these nor those are men. And through this the name is changed, yet the error remains the same both then and now always.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis non intueatur in hac prosecutione tua, levitatis et indiscretionis plena, sicut et in caeteris fecisti, Galliam te quoque complexum?
chunks.english: Who does not see in this prosecution of yours, full of levity and indiscretion, as you have done in other matters, that you have also embraced Gaul?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae utique immaginas sanctorum ob praemissas causas et habet et habere sinit: eas vero adorari, et in daemonum cultum venerari, magnae detestationi et abominationi habet.
chunks.english: Which certainly has images of the saints for the aforementioned reasons and allows them to be had, but has great detestation and abomination for them being adored and venerated in the worship of demons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non igitur, ut asseris, colit idola, et nomen mutavit, quia reliquit diabolum, et secuta est Christum, ac de infideli facta est fidelis.
chunks.english: Therefore, as you assert, it does not worship idols and has changed the name, because it has abandoned the devil and followed Christ, and from unfaithful has become faithful.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Porro immagina sanctorum, ut dictum est, habet, non tamen eas in daemonum cultum veneratur.
chunks.english: Moreover, it has images of the saints, as has been said, yet does not venerate them in the worship of demons.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam et illi qui nimio et indiscreto amore ob honorem sanctorum eorum imaginibus supplicant, nescio an temere idololatrae sint vocandi.
chunks.english: For even those who, out of excessive and indiscrete love for the honor of the saints, supplicate their images, I do not know whether they should be rashly called idolaters.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videntur sane potius ab hac superstitione, adhibito rationis moderamine, revocandi, quam idololatrae, cum utique sanctae Trinitatis fidem veraciter credant et praedicent, nuncupandi.
chunks.english: They seem rather to be recalled from this superstition by applying the moderation of reason than to be called idolaters, since they truly believe and proclaim the faith of the Holy Trinity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caetera vero in eadem assertione tua faciunt nobiscum,excepto eo quod in ea ultimum posuisti, ita inquiens: "Ac per hoc nomen mutatur, error tamen et tunc et nunc idem ipse permanet semper."
chunks.english: But the rest in that assertion of yours they do with us, except for what you placed last in it, saying thus: And through this the name is changed, yet the error remains the same both then and now always.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod superioribus, ubi dixisti: "Non idola reliquerunt, sed nomina mutaverunt," non inconvenienter aptari potest.
chunks.english: Which can be not inappropriately fitted to the earlier words where you said: They have not abandoned idols but have changed the names.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: L'articolo è:
chunks.english: The passage is:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Certe si adorandi fuissent, vivi potius quam mortui, ut tu posuisti, adorandi esse debuerunt."
chunks.english: Certainly if they were to be adored, the living rather than the dead, as you stated, ought to have been adored.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut ponere debueras, adorandi fuissent, aut certe adorari debuerant.
chunks.english: As you should have written: they were to be adored, or certainly they ought to have been adored.
chunks.notes: Grammatical correction noted

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Id est, ubi similitudinem Dei habent."
chunks.english: That is, where they have the likeness of God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nel suo verbis nobiscum sobrie sentis: de qua re sufficientia divinae Scripturae testimonia habentur, quae hic brevitatis causa non ponuntur.
chunks.english: In these words you sense soberly with us. Concerning this matter there are sufficient testimonies of divine Scripture, which are not placed here for the sake of brevity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod autem illico subnettis:
chunks.english: But what you immediately add:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Non ubi pecorum, vel, quod verius est, lapidum, sive lignorum vita, sensu et ratione, ut tu posuisti, carentem."
chunks.english: Not where they have the likeness of beasts, or, what is more true, of stones or woods lacking life, sense, and reason, as you stated.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut ponere debueras; "carentium similitudinem habent."
chunks.english: As you should have written: they have the likeness of things lacking.
chunks.notes: Grammatical correction noted

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantum ab his qui sanum sapiunt perverse dissentias res ipsa liquido prodit, plena quippe sunt blasphemiae verba quae in contemptum sanctorum impudenti ore protulisti.
chunks.english: How perversely you dissent from those who think soundly, the matter itself clearly reveals. For the words you have uttered with shameless mouth in contempt of the saints are full of blasphemy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nimium ergo et infeliciter errando a sensu cunctorum fidelium discrepasti, quando sanctorum pretiosa corpora quae Deo dedicaverunt, et in quibus officiosissime ei servierunt, quae utique organum sancti Spiritus exstiterunt, pecoribus et, ut verius te scripsisse dixisti, lapidibus et lignis coaequasti.
chunks.english: Therefore, erring excessively and unfortunately, you have diverged from the sense of all the faithful when you equated the precious bodies of the saints, which they dedicated to God and in which they most dutifully served him, which indeed were the organ of the Holy Spirit, with beasts and, as you said you wrote more truly, with stones and wood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hac quippe prosecutione tua, qua te sanctorum corpora despectui habere manifestas, errorem Eustathii et Vigilantii omnino sequi convinceris.
chunks.english: By this prosecution of yours, in which you show that you hold the bodies of the saints in contempt, you are convicted of entirely following the error of Eustathius and Vigilantius.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Uterque igitur, sicut jam praemissum est, reliquias sanctorum contemnendas et alia multa contra statuta ecclesiastica insaniendo dogmatizavit, et idcirco merito sub perpetuo anatemate haereticorum collegio datus est.
chunks.english: Each of them therefore, as has already been stated, taught by raving that the relics of the saints should be despised and many other things against ecclesiastical statutes, and therefore was deservedly given to the assembly of heretics under perpetual anathema.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sed juxta cujusdam erroneum dogma (Diogenem scilicet Cynicum dico) feris avibusque projiciantur, aut certe quaquaversum, velut lapis inutilis et lignum infructuosum, dispergantur.
chunks.english: But according to the erroneous teaching of a certain person—I mean Diogenes the Cynic—they should be thrown to wild beasts and birds, or certainly scattered everywhere like a useless stone and unfruitful wood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis catholicorum, rogo te, tam impia tamque blasphema verba patienter vel legere, vel audire possit?
chunks.english: What Catholic, I ask you, could patiently read or hear such impious and blasphemous words?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis, inquam, nisi mentis inops tam profana non exsecretur dicta?
chunks.english: Who, I say, except one bereft of mind, would not execrate such profane sayings?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: An nescis paganis moris fuisse ossa martyrum, quos diversissimis generibus mortium necabant, ne a Christianis honorabiliter sepelirentur, diversissimis modis occuluisse, aut igni concremasse, aut certe feris avibusque exposuisse?
chunks.english: Or do you not know that it was the custom of pagans to hide in various ways the bones of martyrs whom they killed by most diverse kinds of deaths, lest they be buried honorably by Christians, or to burn them with fire, or certainly to expose them to wild beasts and birds?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hoc videlicet per hos, quantum eis possibile fuit, caventibus impuris spiritibus, ne per cineres sanctorum augmentarentur beneficia mortalium, confunderetur pertinacia infidelium, et detegeretur dolositas ipsorum.
chunks.english: This was done by these impure spirits, as far as was possible for them, taking care lest through the ashes of the saints the benefits to mortals be increased, the obstinacy of unbelievers be confounded, and their deceitfulness be exposed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad sanctorum quippe cineres, ut beatus Hieronymus adversus Vigilantium scribit, daemones rugiunt, et de obsessis corporibus aufugiunt, et alia multa innumera, eorum interventu suffragante, et Christi gratia cooperante, fiunt.
chunks.english: At the ashes of the saints, as blessed Jerome writes against Vigilantius, demons roar and flee from possessed bodies, and many other innumerable things happen through their intervention assisting and the grace of Christ cooperating.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad pecorum vero cadavera, et ad lapides, et ad ligna nil tale fieri haud dubium est.
chunks.english: But at the carcasses of beasts, and at stones and wood, there is no doubt that nothing of the kind happens.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: tunc illam terram sepulcrorum mortuorum, quos pro diis colebant, fuisse plenissimam, sed dolor daemonum per eum loquebatur, qui suas futuras poenas apud sanctorum martyrum memorias imminere moerebant.
chunks.english: Then that land was most full of tombs of the dead whom they worshiped as gods, but the sorrow of demons spoke through him, who mourned that their future punishments were imminent at the memorials of the holy martyrs.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In multis enim talibus locis torquentur et confitentur, et de possessis hominum corporibus ejiciuntur.
chunks.english: For in many such places they are tormented and confess and are cast out of the possessed bodies of human beings.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Joannes Crisostomo in homilia de Natali Machabaeorum: Quam speciosa, inquit, et grata festivitas nobis enituit, et totius anni diebus splendidior dies hodierna praefulget?
chunks.english: John Chrysostom in his homily on the Birthday of the Maccabees: How beautiful and pleasing a feast has shone upon us, and brighter than all the days of the whole year does this day shine forth?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non densatis solis radiis illuminata praeclarius, sed de lumine martyrum supra coruscum fulguris micantem illustrata sublimis, multis enim solibus illustriores sunt martyres et magnis luminaribus clariores; propterea hodie, si dici potest, coelo ipso ornatior terra laetatur.
chunks.english: Not more brilliantly illuminated by the concentrated rays of the sun, but sublimely illuminated by the light of the martyrs shining brighter than the flash of lightning. For martyrs are more illustrious than many suns and brighter than great luminaries. Therefore today, if it can be said, the earth rejoices more adorned than heaven itself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed in hac comparatione non attendas cinerem sanctorum corporum, nec favillam reliquiarum carnis, omniaque ossa consumpta temporibus, sed aperi oculos fidei, et vide eos divina virtute et gratia Spiritus sancti amictos, et divini luminis claritate radiantes.
chunks.english: But in this comparison do not regard the ashes of holy bodies, nor the dust of the remains of flesh, and all bones consumed by time, but open the eyes of faith and see them clothed with divine power and the grace of the Holy Spirit, and radiating with the brightness of divine light.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hi ergo ipsi de superno Solis circulo in terram radii, Christo emittente, jaciuntur, et a corporibus suis prosilientes corusca luce fulgoris, sicut speciem Ecclesiae gaudentis illustrant, ita faciem diaboli invidentis obcaecant.
chunks.english: These very rays therefore are cast from the circle of the heavenly Sun onto the earth, with Christ sending them forth. And leaping from their bodies with the brilliant light of splendor, just as they illuminate the appearance of the rejoicing Church, so they blind the face of the envious devil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam ut audaces latronum duces, sive impii sepulcrorum effossores, si forte dum praedas agunt, aut spolia capienda conquirunt, in arma vel ornamenta imperatoris incurrerint, quamlibet cupidi praedarum, tamen agnitis regis insignibus deterrentur ut fugiant, neque cominus accedere vel attingere audeant, unde sibi non compendio procedere, sed periculum praevident imminere, si quid inde audeant usurpare.
chunks.english: For just as bold leaders of robbers, or impious grave diggers, if by chance while they are hunting plunder or seeking spoils to be taken, they should run into the arms or ornaments of the emperor, however greedy for plunder, nevertheless, recognizing the insignia of the king, they are deterred so that they flee, and dare not approach closely or touch, from which they foresee not profit proceeding but danger imminent if they dare to seize anything from it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ita profecto et daemones, qui vere latronum et principes et magistri sunt, ubi coronatorum martyrum corpora viderint posita, longe illico a conspectu eorum pavidi fugiunt et absiliunt.
chunks.english: So indeed also demons, who truly are both princes and teachers of robbers, when they see the bodies of crowned martyrs placed, immediately flee terrified far from their sight and leap away.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim naturam eorum attendunt, sed in arcanam dignitatem et gloriam Christi, qui in agone certaminum induta corpora martyrum suorum sicut arma portavit.
chunks.english: For they do not regard their nature, but the hidden dignity and glory of Christ, who bore the bodies of his martyrs clothed in the contest of struggles like armor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hujusmodi enim arma non angelus, non archangelus, non ulla alia creaturae virtus induta est, sed ipse Dominus virtutum et angelorum, sicut Paulus clamat, II Corinto. XIII dicens: Si experimentum quaeritis praeliantis in me Christi.
chunks.english: For such armor has not been put on by an angel, not by an archangel, not by any other power of creation, but by the Lord himself of powers and angels, as Paul cries out in his second letter to the Corinthians, chapter thirteen, saying: If you seek proof of Christ speaking in me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pretiosa enim sunt martyrum corpora, quoniam plagas pro Domino susceperunt, et quia stigmata propter Christum membris suis impressa ferunt; et sicut corona regalis, undique decorata, fulgores varios emittit, ita et sanctorum martyrum corpora, sicut pretiosis lapidibus,exceptis pro Christo vulneribus distintia, omni regum diademate pretiosiora et spectabiliora redduntur.
chunks.english: For precious are the bodies of martyrs, because they received wounds for the Lord, and because they bear stigmata impressed on their members for Christ. And just as a royal crown, adorned on all sides, emits various splendors, so also the bodies of the holy martyrs, distinguished as if with precious stones by the wounds received for Christ, are rendered more precious and more worthy of regard than any diadem of kings.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec ille.
chunks.english: Thus he said.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur his et innumeris aliis sanctorum Patrum documentis declaratur quod sanctorum corpora pretiosa sint, et a cunctis fidelibus veneranda et honoranda, liquet profecto quia infidelium est ea contemnere, et fidelium ea humaniter terrae mandare, et ob ejus amorem pro cujus nomine passi sunt, honorare.
chunks.english: Therefore, since by these and innumerable other teachings of the holy Fathers it is declared that the bodies of the saints are precious and to be venerated and honored by all the faithful, it is certainly clear that it belongs to unbelievers to despise them, and to believers to commit them humanely to the earth and to honor them for the love of him for whose name they suffered.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quorum alterum impietatis est quidem, alterum vero pietatis constat esse indicium.
chunks.english: Of which the former is indeed a sign of impiety, but the latter is established to be a sign of piety.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter quisquis ea contemnenda judicat, aut corporibus pecorum, vel lapidibus, aut certe lignis simillima esse contendit, non Christianus, sed Eustathianus et Vigilantianus, et, quod verius ferendum est, infidelis habendus est.
chunks.english: Wherefore whoever judges that they should be despised or contends that they are most similar to the bodies of beasts or stones or certainly wood, should be held not as a Christian but as a follower of Eustathius and Vigilantius, and, what is more truly to be stated, as an unbeliever.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: pecorum, vel lapidum, et lignorum similitudinem habent, quid dicturus es de miraculis quae, Christi potentia operante, apud eorum memorias mirabiliter fiunt?
chunks.english: If they have the likeness of beasts or stones and wood, what will you say about the miracles which, by the power of Christ working, happen marvelously at their memorials?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Manifestum est enim cunctis fidelibus eorumdem sanctorum corpora multis magnisque miraculis divinitus honorari, nec immerito?
chunks.english: For it is manifest to all the faithful that the bodies of these same saints are divinely honored with many and great miracles, and not undeservedly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aequum quippe est ut qui corpora sua membra justitiae utiliter exhibuerunt et in eis diabolum triumpharunt, tam evidentibus coruscent miraculis, quatenus praeclaris divinae remunerazioneis appareat indiciis quam pretiosa sit mors in conspectu Domini, et quod magna sit eorum virtus apud Altissimum (Sal. XXV).
chunks.english: For it is fitting that those who usefully presented their bodies as members of righteousness and triumphed over the devil in them should shine with such evident miracles, so that by the illustrious signs of divine recompense it may appear how precious is their death in the sight of the Lord, and that great is their power with the Most High, as found in Psalm twenty-five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At si nunc corpora sanctorum in pulverem cineremve jam pene redacta, tantis divina pietate munerantur miraculis, quantis putas resurretionis tempore perpetuis donabuntur praemiis?
chunks.english: But if now the bodies of the saints, already almost reduced to dust and ashes, are rewarded with such great miracles by divine piety, with how many do you think they will be endowed with perpetual rewards at the time of resurrection?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod autem corpora defunctorum, maxime justorum, non sint abjicienda, sed potius terrae mandanda, docet beatus Augustinus in libro de Civitate Dei primo: Nec contemnenda sunt, inquit, et abjicienda corpora defunctorum, maximeque justorum atque fidelium, quibus tanquam organis et vasis ad omnia bona opera sanctus Spiritus usus est.
chunks.english: But that the bodies of the dead, especially of the just, should not be cast away but rather committed to the earth, blessed Augustine teaches in the first book of The City of God: The bodies of the dead, he says, especially of the just and faithful, by which the Holy Spirit used as organs and vessels for all good works, should neither be despised nor cast away.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod vero corpora sanctorum sint a fidelibus honoranda, scribit beato Hieronymus ad Riparium contra Vigilantium: Honoramus, inquit reliquias martyrum, ut eum, cujus martyres sunt, adoremus.
chunks.english: That the bodies of the saints should be honored by the faithful, blessed Jerome writes to Riparius against Vigilantius: We honor, he says, the relics of martyrs, so that we may adore him whose martyrs they are.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Honoramus servis, ut honor servorum redundet ad Dominum, qui ait: Qui vos suscipit, ecc. (Mt. X).
chunks.english: We honor the servants so that the honor of the servants may redound to the Lord, who says: Whoever receives you, and so on, as found in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter ten.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tantorum autem doctorum salutiferis declaratur documentis, quod sanctorum corpora non sint (secundum naenias et ineptias tuas) pecoribus, vel lapidibus et lignis coaequanda, sed magis a cunctis fidelibus pio amore amplectenda et honoranda.
chunks.english: But by the saving teachings of such great doctors it is declared that the bodies of the saints should not be, according to your trifles and foolishness, equated with beasts or stones and wood, but rather should be embraced and honored by all the faithful with pious love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo liquet te negare non posse quod sanctorum corpora non sint his rebus quas scripsisti comparanda, sed magis ab Ecclesiae catholicae filiis honoranda, et quod ob meritorum praerogativam tot tantisque rutilent miraculis, necesse est ut, omni obstinatione remota, humiliter confitearis te errasse quando ea pecorum et lapidum, et lignorum similitudinem habere dixisti: et licet pertinaciae deditus hoc facere contempseris, veritate tamen et ratione evidenter errasse convinceris.
chunks.english: Since therefore it is clear that you cannot deny that the bodies of the saints should not be compared to those things you wrote, but rather should be honored by the sons of the Catholic Church, and that they shine with so many and such great miracles because of the prerogative of their merits, it is necessary that, with all obstinacy removed, you humbly confess that you erred when you said they have the likeness of beasts and stones and wood. And although, devoted to obstinacy, you have scorned to do this, nevertheless by truth and reason you are evidently convicted of having erred.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Utrum autem ipsi exanimis corporibus suis praesto sint, cum beneficia praestantur mortalibus, necne, beati Augustini salutiferis documentis, scribentis in libris de Civitate Dei et in libro de Cura agenda pro mortuis, nec non beati Gregorii libro Dialogorum, plenissime instruimur, ad quorum lectionem diligentem curiosumque mittimus lectorem.
chunks.english: But whether they themselves are present to their lifeless bodies when benefits are rendered to mortals or not, we are most fully instructed by the saving teachings of blessed Augustine writing in his books of The City of God and in his book On Care to Be Taken for the Dead, as well as by the book of Dialogues of blessed Gregory, to the diligent and careful reading of which we send the reader.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sequitur in eodem opere tuo:
chunks.english: There follows in your same work:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Ex qua re, inquit, summopere pensandum est, quia si opera manuum Dei non sunt adoranda et colenda, quanto magis opera manuum hominum adoranda et colenda non sunt?
chunks.english: He says, From this matter it must be especially considered that if the works of God's hands are not to be adored and worshiped, how much more are the works of human hands not to be adored and worshiped?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prorsus nec in honore eorum quorum similitudines esse dicuntur."
chunks.english: And absolutely not in honor of those whose likenesses they are said to be.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In hujus sententiae sensu nobiscum sobrie sapis.
chunks.english: In the sense of this statement you think soberly with us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum est, inquam, quia neque opera manuum hominum sunt adoranda et colenda, illo videlicet cultu et adoratione qui solius Divinitatis est.
chunks.english: It is true, I say, because neither are the works of human hands to be adored and worshiped with that worship and adoration which belongs to divinity alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: et honoranda, ut pote sancti Spiritus templa sacrata.
chunks.english: And to be honored, as consecrated temples of the Holy Spirit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed et illud quod subjungis:
chunks.english: But also what you add:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Quia si imago, quam adoras, Deus non est, nequaquam veneranda est honore sanctorum, qui nequaquam divinos sibi arrogante honores;"
chunks.english: Because if the image which you adore is not God, it is by no means to be venerated with the honor of the saints, who by no means claim divine honors for themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: omnino approbamus congruumque fidei catholicae esse judicamus.
chunks.english: We entirely approve and judge to be fitting to the Catholic faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Articolo paulo post:
chunks.english: A passage shortly after:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Et ideo, inquit, sciendum summopere est quia non solum qui visibilia figmenta atque imagines colit, sed etiam quamlibet, sive coelestem, sive terrenam, sive spiritalem, sive corpoream creaturam, vice nominis Dei colit, et salutem animae suae quae a Deo solo est, ab illis sperat, de illis est, de quibus dicit Apostolus: Et coluerunt, et servierunt creaturae potius quam Creatori (Rom. I)."
chunks.english: And therefore, he says, it must be especially known that not only whoever worships visible fictions and images, but also whoever worships any creature, whether celestial or earthly, whether spiritual or corporeal, in place of the name of God, and hopes for the salvation of his soul, which is from God alone, from them, is of those concerning whom the Apostle says: They worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, as found in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: His tuis verbis breviter respondemus: Nos figmenta et imagines non colimus.
chunks.english: To these words of yours we respond briefly: We do not worship fictions and images.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Immagina tamen et habemus, et habentibus non praejudicamus.
chunks.english: Yet we have images, and we do not prejudge those who have them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quisquis vero visibilia figmenta atque immaginas, et sive coelestem, sive terrenam, sive spiritualem, sive corporem creaturam pro Deo colit, creaturae non Creatori servire convincitur.
chunks.english: But whoever worships visible fictions and images, and whether celestial or earthly, whether spiritual or corporeal creature in place of God, is convicted of serving the creature, not the Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Salutem sane animae nostrae a solo Deo dari fideliter credimus; sed quia, meritis nostris praepedientibus, eam ab eo nancisci non meremur, si suffragiis coelestium, sive spiritualium creaturarum illius nos compotes fore veraciter confidimus, nequaquam creaturae, ut scripsisti, sed potius Creatori servire comprobamur.
chunks.english: We faithfully believe that the salvation of our soul is given by God alone. But because, with our merits hindering, we do not deserve to obtain it from him, if we truly trust that we shall become partakers of it through the intercessions of heavenly or spiritual creatures, we are proved to serve by no means the creature, as you wrote, but rather the Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At si per sanctorum suffragia salus animarum non acquiritur, utquid eorum intercessio in missarum Celebrationibus et caeteris humillimis supplicationibus apud divinam majestatem flagitatur?
chunks.english: But if the salvation of souls is not acquired through the intercessions of the saints, why is their intercession sought at the divine majesty in the celebrations of masses and other most humble supplications?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Salus igitur animae, scimus quia non nisi a Deo datur, sed fideliter credimus quod per eorum interventum nobis immeritis ab eo largiatur, et pro eo quod id credimus et speramus, non creaturae, sed Creatori nostro servimus.
chunks.english: Therefore, we know that the salvation of the soul is given only by God, but we faithfully believe that through their intervention it is granted to us undeserving from him. And because we believe and hope this, we serve not the creature but our Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: L'articolo è:
chunks.english: The passage is:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Quid te ad falsas immaginas humilias et inclinas?
chunks.english: Why do you humble and bow yourself to false images?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ante inepta simulacra, et figmenta terrena, captiva, corpore incurvas?
chunks.english: Why do you bend your body before foolish idols and earthly fictions, captive?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rectum te Deus fecit, et cum caetera animalia prona et ad terram, situ urgente, depressa sint, tibi sublimis status et ad coelum atque ad Dominum vultus rectus est.
chunks.english: God made you upright, and while other animals are prone and pressed down to the earth by their position, for you there is an upright stance and a face directed toward heaven and toward the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ad alta et coelestia suspensum pectus attolle.
chunks.english: Lift up your heart suspended toward high and heavenly things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid te in lapsum mortis cum insensata immagina, quam colis, sternis?
chunks.english: Why do you prostrate yourself into the fall of death with the senseless image which you worship?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid in ruinam diaboli per ipsa et cum ipsa cadis?
chunks.english: Why do you fall into the ruin of the devil through it and with it?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sublimitatem serva qua natus es; perseverare talis qualis a Deo factus es."
chunks.english: Preserve the sublimity in which you were born; persevere as you were made by God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec non tua, Claudi, sed beati Cypriani sunt martyris verba, e quibus quaedam subtraxisti, quaedam immutasti, et ut tua propria posuisti.
chunks.english: These are not your words, Claudius, but the words of blessed Cyprian the martyr, from which you have removed some parts, changed some, and set them forth as your own.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit itaque idem eximius doctor ad Demetrianum, idololatriae cultui deditum haec verba, ita inquiens: Quid te ad falsos deos humilias et inclinas?
chunks.english: Therefore, that same distinguished doctor writes these words to Demetrian, devoted to the worship of idolatry, saying thus: Why do you humble and bow yourself to false gods?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ante inepta simulacra et figmenta terrena captivum corpus incurvas?
chunks.english: Why do you bend your captive body before foolish idols and earthly fictions?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rectum te fecit Deus: et cum caetera animalia prona et ad terram situ vergente depressa sint, tibi sublimis status et ad coelum atque Deum tuum vultus erectus est: illuc intuere, illic oculos tuos erige, in supernis Deum quaere, ut carere inferis possis.
chunks.english: God made you upright. And while other animals are prone and pressed down toward the earth by their position, for you there is an upright stance and a face lifted toward heaven and your God. Look there, raise your eyes there, seek God in the heights so that you may be able to lack the lower things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad alta et coelestia suspensum pectus attolle.
chunks.english: Lift up your heart suspended toward high and heavenly things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid te in lapsum mortis cum serpente (quem colis) sternis?
chunks.english: Why do you prostrate yourself into the fall of death with the serpent which you worship?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid in ruinam diaboli per ipsum et cum ipso cadis?
chunks.english: Why do you fall into the ruin of the devil through it and with it?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sublimitatem serva qua natus es; persevera talis qualis a Deo factus es: cum statu oris et corporis animum tuum statua; ut cognoscere Deum possis, te ante cognosce.
chunks.english: Preserve the sublimity in which you were born; persevere as you were made by God. With the stance of your mouth and body, establish your mind. That you may be able to know God, first know yourself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mirari nequeo satis quod tam clanculo alterius verba furari volueris, et quod idem furtum alios latere posse ratus sis.
chunks.english: I cannot sufficiently marvel that you wished to steal another's words so secretly and that you thought the same theft could escape the notice of others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nescisne quid Dominus de furantibus verba sua per prophetam dicat? (Ger. XXIII.)
chunks.english: Do you not know what the Lord says through the prophet concerning those who steal his words, as found in Jeremiah, chapter twenty-three?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Credo etiam te legisse Cassiodorum, qui quale officium sit compilatorum in explicatione plenissime exsequitur Psalmorum.
chunks.english: I believe also that you have read Cassiodorus, who most fully explains what the duty of compilers is in his exposition of the Psalms.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Constat igitur te in hoc facto imperite et reprensibiliter egisse, et idcirco necesse est ut ingenue fatearis te in eodem facto errasse.
chunks.english: It is therefore established that you acted unskillfully and reprehensibly in this deed, and therefore it is necessary that you frankly confess that you erred in the same deed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum quincunque sua errata confiteri detrectat, aliorum procul dubio libera fronte nec reprehendere nec corrigere valet, audiens a Domino: Quare tu enarras justitias meas, et assumis Testamentum meum per os tuum?
chunks.english: But whoever refuses to confess his errors certainly cannot with free countenance either reprove or correct those of others, hearing from the Lord: Why do you declare my justices and take my testament in your mouth?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tu vero odisti disciplinam, et projecisti sermones meos retrorsum (Sal. XLIX).
chunks.english: But you have hated discipline and cast my words behind you, as found in Psalm forty-nine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et in Evangelio: Quid ergo vides festucam in oculo fratris tui, trabem autem quae est in oculo tuo non consideras? et reliqua. (Mt. VII, Lc. VI.)
chunks.english: And in the Gospel: Why do you see the speck in your brother's eye, but do not consider the beam that is in your own eye? and the rest, as found in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter seven, and the Gospel of Luke, chapter six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo certum est alterius verba tua propria fecisse violenter, quaero ab te cur in loco ubi beatus Cyprianus posuit: "Quid te ad falsos deos humilias et inclinas?"
chunks.english: Since therefore it is certain that you have violently made another's words your own, I ask you why in the place where blessed Cyprian placed: Why do you humble and bow yourself to false gods?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tu "falsas imagines" scripseris?
chunks.english: You wrote false images?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille falsos deos dixit, quia veri non sunt: ​​immagina porro, si immagina sunt aut hominum, aut quarumlibet aliarum rerum, quomodo falsum sit eas immaginas video non esse, non satis.
chunks.english: He said false gods because they are not true. But as for images, if they are images either of humans or of any other things, how it is false that they are images I do not sufficiently see.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si responderis eas falsas esse idcirco quia nihil veritatis in se habent, quoniam cum habeant similitudines humanorum corporum, non tamen vera sunt corpora, idcirco eas merito falsas appellari: immaginas tamen in veritate eas esse nullatenus negare poteris.
chunks.english: But if you respond that they are false because they have nothing of truth in themselves, since although they have likenesses of human bodies, they are not nevertheless true bodies, and therefore they are deservedly called false—yet you will by no means be able to deny that they are truly images.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod cum non possis, justa reprehensione supervacue falsas eas posuisse denotaris.
chunks.english: Since you cannot do this, you are shown by just reproof to have superfluously called them false.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam et in eo quod paulo post posuisti: "Quid te ante inepta simulacra et figmenta terrena captiva, corpore incurvas?"
chunks.english: For also in what you placed shortly after: Why do you bend your body before foolish idols and earthly fictions, captive?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: utquid figmenta terrena captiva ducere volueris, necesse est ut exponas.
chunks.english: Why you wished to call earthly fictions captive, it is necessary that you explain.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid figmenta terrena sint, non ignoramus; captiva vero quomodo dici possint, merito quaeritur.
chunks.english: We do not ignore what earthly fictions are; but how they can be called captive is rightly questioned.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si captiva sunt, a quo in hujusmodi captivitatem devenerunt?
chunks.english: If they are captive, by whom have they come into such captivity?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod cum tua esposizione non egeat, quia ipso dictu absurdum est, constat te tam vesano furore correptum, ut prorsus nescias quid dicis.
chunks.english: Since this does not need your explanation, because it is absurd by the very saying of it, it is established that you are seized by such mad fury that you utterly do not know what you are saying.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Exstant et alia quae de verbis ejusdem sanctissimi viri furtim usurpasti, et non eo ordine verborum quo ab ipso posita, vel eo sensu quo dicta sunt, sed ad peregrinum quemdam intellectum violenter pro libitu tuoi retorsisti.
chunks.english: There exist also other things which you have furtively usurped from the words of that same most holy man, and you have twisted them violently according to your pleasure, not in the order of words in which they were placed by him, nor in the sense in which they were said, but toward a certain foreign understanding.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae si, ut a te immutata et posita sunt, lectoris prudentia discuti et examinari coeperint, quantae absurditatis, quantaeve reprehensionis sint; et quam coacte fluenta, quae limpida hausisti, pede pravi intellectus turbaveris, liquido patebit.
chunks.english: Which, if they begin to be discerned and examined by the prudence of the reader as they have been changed and placed by you, how much absurdity and how much reprehension there is, and how forcibly you have troubled with the foot of perverse understanding the streams which you drew clear, will clearly appear.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: L'articolo è:
chunks.english: The passage is:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: "Sed dicunt isti falsae religionis atque superstitionis cultores: Nos ob recordationem Salvatoris nostri crucem pictam atque in ejus honorem imaginatam colimus, veneramur atque adoramus."
chunks.english: But these worshipers of false religion and superstition say: We worship, venerate, and adore the cross painted and imagined in his honor for the remembrance of our Savior.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quos supra membra diaboli, hos hic infausto et impudenti ore falsae religionis atque superstitionis cultores appellas, causamque protinus reddere videri vis, cur falsae religionis atque superstitionis cultores appellantur, eo quod scilicet ob memoriam passionis Christi crucem pictam atque in ejus honorem imaginatam colant, venerentur atque adorante.
chunks.english: Those whom above you called members of the devil, these here with unfortunate and shameless mouth you call worshipers of false religion and superstition, and you immediately seem to want to give the reason why they are called worshipers of false religion and superstition, because namely for the memory of the passion of Christ they worship, venerate, and adore the cross painted and imagined in his honor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod ergo ob recordationem redemptionis suae sancta Ecclesia ex sanctorum Patrum traditione crucem Christi veneretur, adoret, colat, non cultu et adoratione quae solius Divinitatis est, sed eo potius unde [de quo] satis abundeque supra dictum est, nemo nisi qui ab ecclesiastica tradizionee dissentit, ignorat.
chunks.english: That the holy Church therefore venerates, adores, and worships the cross of Christ from the tradition of the holy Fathers for the remembrance of its redemption, not with the worship and adoration which belongs to divinity alone, but rather with that concerning which enough and abundantly has been said above—no one is ignorant except one who dissents from ecclesiastical tradition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde ob recordationem salutiferae passionis Dominicae annuatim in sanctissimo die Parasceves, secundum traditionem ecclesiasticam, crucem Christi adorat, id est, supplicando salutat, quae etiam totum diffusa per orbem in Christi laudem prorumpens gratulabunda canit: Crucem tuam adoramus, Domine, et sanctam resurrezionem tuam laudamus et glorificamus.
chunks.english: Whence, for the remembrance of the saving passion of the Lord, annually on the most holy day of Good Friday, according to ecclesiastical tradition, it adores the cross of Christ—that is, it greets it by supplication. Spread throughout the whole world, it also bursts forth rejoicing in the praise of Christ and sings: We adore your cross, O Lord, and we praise and glorify your holy resurrection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et iterum: Ecce lignum crucis, in quo salus mundi pependit; venite, adoramus.
chunks.english: And again: Behold the wood of the cross on which the salvation of the world hung; come, let us adore.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et beato Gregorius, de cujus dictis nemo nisi immemor salutis suae ambigit, in libro Sacramentorum ita meminit: Deus, qui unigeniti tui Domini nostri Jesu Christi pretioso sanguine humanum genus redimere dignatus es, concede propitius ut qui ad adorandam vivificam crucem adveniunt, a peccatorum suorum nexibus liberentur.
chunks.english: And blessed Gregory, of whose sayings no one doubts except one unmindful of his salvation, mentions thus in the book of Sacraments: O God, who deigned to redeem the human race by the precious blood of your only-begotten Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, mercifully grant that those who come to adore the life-giving cross may be freed from the bonds of their sins.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quaero abs te, Claudi, si aliquando hanc orationem Domino decantasti, cum a te ventum fuit ad locum adorandae crucis, quid ibi dixeris: sed reor te imitatum Judaeos, quos Apostolus flendo inimicos crucis Christi (Fil. III) dicit, adeo ejusdem crucis inimicum factum, ut verbum adorandae crucis aut penitus praeterieris, aut certe immutando juxta familiarissimum tibi modum aliud pro alio dixeris, sicut in verbis beati Cypriani martyris convinceris fecisse.
chunks.english: I ask you, Claudius, if you ever sang this prayer to the Lord, when you came to the place of adoring the cross, what you said there. But I believe you imitated the Jews, whom the Apostle says weeping are enemies of the cross of Christ in his letter to the Philippians, chapter three, to such an extent that you became an enemy of that same cross, so that you either completely passed over the word of adoring the cross, or certainly by changing, according to your most familiar manner, you said something else for another, as you are convicted of having done in the words of blessed Cyprian the martyr.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter, sicut in evertendis imaginibus sanctorum et ab ecclesiis penitus pellendis, beati et excellentissimi doctoris Gregorii scribentis ad Serenum Massiliensem episcopum, saluberrimis dictis contumaciter contraisti: ita nihilominus in abdicandis ab ecclesia Christi crucibus et despectui habendis, ejusdem doctoris factis et dictis irreverenter imprudenterque comprobaris obviasse.
chunks.english: Wherefore, just as in overturning the images of the saints and completely expelling them from churches, you have obstinately opposed the most salutary sayings of the blessed and most excellent doctor Gregory writing to Serenus, bishop of Marseilles, so likewise you are proved to have irreverently and imprudently opposed the deeds and sayings of that same doctor in renouncing and holding in contempt the crosses of the church of Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit itaque idem doctor ad Januarium episcopum, ita inquiens: Judaei, de civitate vestra huc venientes, questi nobis sunt quod synagogam eorum quae Caralis sita est, Petrus qui ex eorum superstitione ad Christianae fidei cultum, Deo volente, perductus est, adhibitis sibi quibusdam indisciplinatis, sequenti die battesimatis sui, hoc est, Dominica [in] ipsa festivitate Paschali, cum gravi scandalo sine vestra occupaverit voluntate, atque imaginem illic genitricis Dei, Dominique nostri, et venerandam crucem, vel pyrrhum albam qua de fronte surgens indutus fuerat, apposuisset.
chunks.english: Therefore, that same doctor writes to Bishop Januarius, saying thus: Jews coming here from your city have complained to us that their synagogue which is situated at Cagliari, Peter, who from their superstition was led to the worship of the Christian faith by God's will, having associated with himself certain undisciplined people, on the day following his baptism, that is, on the very Sunday of the Paschal feast, occupied it with great scandal without your consent, and had placed there an image of the Mother of God and our Lord, and the venerable cross, or the white garment with which he had been clothed rising from the font.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: E paulo post: Considerantes, inquit, hac de re vestrae voluntatis intentum ac magis judicium, his hortamur affatibus, ut, sublata exinde, cum ea qua dignum est veneratione, imagine atque cruce, debeatis quod violenter ablatum est, reformare.
chunks.english: And shortly after: Considering, he says, the intent and rather the judgment of your will concerning this matter, we exhort with these words that, with the image and cross having been removed from there with the veneration which is worthy, you should restore what has been violently taken away.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Item idem ad Recharedum regem Wisigothorum scribit inter caetera ita: Crucem quoque latori praesentium dedimus vobis offerendam, in qua lignum Dominicae crucis inest, et capilli beati Joannis Baptistae, ex qua semper solatium nostri Salvatoris per intercessionem praecursoris Domini habeatis.
chunks.english: Likewise, the same author writes to Recared, king of the Visigoths, among other things thus: We have also given to the bearer of these presents a cross to be offered to you, in which there is wood of the Lord's cross and hairs of blessed John the Baptist, from which you may always have the consolation of our Savior through the intercession of the Lord's precursor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scribit etiam Beda venerabilis presbyter, modernique temporis hujus peritissimus ac praeclarissimus doctor, in Historia Anglorum, qualiter eodem beato Gregorio dirigente salubriterque docente, Augustinus episcopus cum sociis suis Britanniam venerit, regemque Anglorum adierit, ita dicens: Post dies ergo aliquot venit ad insulam rex, et residens sub dio, jussit Augustinum cum sociis ad suum ibidem advenire colloquio.
chunks.english: Bede the Venerable priest, most skilled and most illustrious doctor of this modern time, also writes in his History of the English how, with the same blessed Gregory directing and teaching salutarily, Augustine the bishop came to Britain with his companions and approached the king of the English, saying thus: Therefore after some days the king came to the island, and sitting in the open air, he ordered Augustine with his companions to come there for a conversation with him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caverat enim ne in aliquam domum ad se introirent, vetere usus augurio, ne superventu suo si quid maleficae artis habuissent, eum superando deciperent.
chunks.english: For he had taken care lest they should enter into any house to him, using an old omen, lest by their arrival, if they had anything of evil art, they should overcome and deceive him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: At illi non daemoniaca, sed divina praediti virtute veniebant, crucem pro vexillo ferentes argenteam, et imaginem Domini Salvatoris in tabula describeam, litaniasque canentes, pro sua simul et eorum propter quos venerant salute aeterna Domino supplicabant.
chunks.english: But they came endowed not with demonic but with divine power, carrying a silver cross for a banner, and an image of the Lord Savior painted on a board. And singing litanies, they supplicated the Lord both for their own eternal salvation and for those for whom they had come.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et post pauca: Fertur autem quia appropinquantes civitati, more suo cum cruce sancta et imagine magni regis Domini nostri Jesu Christi hanc litaniam consona voce modularentur: Deprecamur te, Domine, in omni misericordia tua, ut auferatur furor tuus, et ira tua a civitate ista, et de domo sancta tua, quoniam peccavimo, alleluia.
chunks.english: And after a few words: It is related that as they approached the city, according to their custom, with the holy cross and the image of the great king, our Lord Jesus Christ, they chanted this litany with harmonious voice: We beseech you, O Lord, in all your mercy, that your fury and your anger may be taken away from this city and from your holy house, because we have sinned, alleluia.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Attende, hortor te, Claudi, patienter, quantus qualisque doctor, et superius crucem juxta praemissum modum adorandam, et in scriptis crucem venerandam astruat, venerationisque causa ac benedictionis, Recharedo regi crucem miserit, quantaque doctrina discipulum suum Augustinum sociosque ejus imbuerit, ut crucem et imaginem Dei nostri Jesu Christi ad fera corda gentilium domanda et praedicanda, et ad fidem Christi convertenda, secum ferret: et perpende quia sanae sobriaeque ejus doctrinae tua insana et inepta resultat doctrina.
chunks.english: Pay attention, I urge you, Claudius, patiently, how great and what sort of doctor he is who both above asserts that the cross is to be adored according to the aforementioned manner, and in his writings that the cross is to be venerated, and for the sake of veneration and blessing sent a cross to King Recared, and with what great teaching he imbued his disciple Augustine and his companions, so that he might carry with him the cross and the image of our God Jesus Christ to tame and preach to the fierce hearts of the gentiles and to convert them to the faith of Christ. And consider that your insane and inept doctrine clashes with his sound and sober doctrine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quoniam quod ille de cruce et imaginibus sanctorum disertissima assertione et cautissimastitutione tenendum docuit, homo tu portentuosis disputationibus labefactandum oblatras.
chunks.english: Because what he taught with most articulate assertion and most careful instruction should be held concerning the cross and images of the saints, you, a man, bark that it should be overthrown with monstrous disputations.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scito ergo quia nisi tua errata humiliter confiteri et corrigere praepropere studueris, procul dubio ad periculum salutis tuae et ad ruinam gradus tui, tanti doctoris excellentissimis dictis et discretissimisstitutionibus contraria dogmatizasti:
chunks.english: Know therefore that unless you hasten to humbly confess and correct your errors, you have doubtless taught, to the peril of your salvation and to the ruin of your rank, doctrines contrary to the most excellent sayings and most discerning institutions of so great a doctor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Contra quos, inquis, respondendum est quia si omne lignum schemate crucis factum volunt adorare, pro eo quod Christus in cruce pependit, et alia multa illis convenit [adorare] quae Christus egit per carnem.
chunks.english: Against them, you say, it must be answered that if they wish to venerate every piece of wood made in the shape of a cross because Christ hung on the cross, then they ought also to venerate many other things that Christ did through his flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vix enim sex horis in cruce pependit, et tamen novem mensibus lunaribus, et super undecim diebus in utero Virginis fuit, qui simul dies solares ducenti septuaginta sex, id est novem menses, et supra dies sex: adorentur ergo puellae virgines, quia virgo peperit Christum.
chunks.english: For he hung on the cross scarcely six hours, yet he was in the Virgin's womb for nine lunar months and eleven days besides, which together make two hundred seventy-six solar days, that is, nine months and six days more. Therefore let them venerate young virgins, because a virgin gave birth to Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adorentur et praesepia, quia mox natus in praesepio est reclinatus. Adorentur et veteres panni, quia continuo cum natus esset, pannis veteribus est involutus.
chunks.english: Let them also venerate mangers, because as soon as he was born he was laid in a manger. Let them venerate old cloths, because immediately when he was born he was wrapped in old rags.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adorentur et naves, quia frequenter in navibus navigavit, et de navicula turbas docuit, et in navi dormivit, et in dextera navigii rete mittere jussit, quando perpedita illa magna captura facta est piscium.
chunks.english: Let them venerate boats, because he frequently sailed in boats, taught the crowds from a little boat, slept in a boat, and commanded the nets to be cast on the right side of the vessel when that great catch of fish was made.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adorentur asini, quia asellum sedendo ad Jerusalem usque pervenit. Adorentur agni, quia de illo scriptum est: Ecce Agnus Dei, qui tollit peccata mundi (Giovanna I); sed isti perversorum dogmatum cultores agnos vivos volunt vorare, et in pariete pictos adorare.
