chunks.english: Let them venerate donkeys, because riding on a donkey he came all the way to Jerusalem. Let them venerate lambs, because it is written of him in the Gospel of John, chapter one: Behold the Lamb of God, who takes away the sins of the world. But these devotees of perverse doctrines want to devour living lambs and venerate those painted on walls.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adorentur et leones, quia de illo scriptum est: Vicit leo de tribu Juda radix David (Apoc. V). Adorentur et petrae, quia quando de cruce est depositus, in saxeo sepulcro est positus.
chunks.english: Let them also venerate lions, because it is written of him in the book of Revelation, chapter five: The lion of the tribe of Judah, the root of David, has conquered. Let them venerate rocks, because when he was taken down from the cross, he was placed in a tomb carved from stone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et de illo dicit Apostolus (I Cor. X): Petra autem erat Christus. Sed Christus, petra, agnus, leo, tropice, non proprie, est dictus, per significantiam, non per substantiam.
chunks.english: And the Apostle says of him in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter ten: The rock was Christ. But Christ is called rock, lamb, and lion figuratively, not literally—by signification, not by substance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adoratore et spinae ruborum, quia exinde spinea corona tempore passionis capiti ejus imposita est. Adorentur et arundines, quia ab eis colaphis a militibus capu ejus caesum est., unde formatur Ecclesia.
chunks.english: Let them venerate thorns and brambles, because from these a crown of thorns was placed on his head at the time of his passion. Let them venerate reeds, because with these his head was struck with blows by the soldiers, from which the Church is formed.
chunks.notes: The final phrase 'unde formatur Ecclesia' is somewhat unclear in context but likely refers to the Church being formed through Christ's passion

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum debueris, Claudi, memor salutis tuae esse, tandemque vanissimae garrulitati tuae modum imponere, e contrario in barathrum blasphemiae eo usque miserabiliter deemergeris, ut virtutem venerationemque crucis quibusdam absonis comparationibus et frivolis Declarationibus atque argumentationibus quodammodo annullare nitaris.
chunks.english: When you ought, Claudius, to be mindful of your salvation and finally set limits to your most vain prattling, on the contrary you have plunged miserably into the abyss of blasphemy to such an extent that you try in some way to nullify the power and veneration of the cross through certain absurd comparisons and frivolous declarations and arguments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur persecutionis tuae assertio, et secundum litterarum disciplinam, et secundum catholicum intellectum fragili structura constabilita est, non habens fundamentum supra petram, merito in utroque labefactatur.
chunks.english: Therefore, since the assertion of your prosecution is established on a fragile structure both according to literary discipline and according to Catholic understanding, not having its foundation upon the rock, it deservedly collapses on both counts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Reprehensiones porro, quae, secundum artis grammaticae peritissimos scriptores, huic insunt pericopae, commenti tui brevitati studentes omittimus, et quid in eadem prosecutione tua stolidissima innuere volueris, pro modulo capacitatis nostrae discutiere nitamur;
chunks.english: Moreover, the criticisms that, according to the most expert writers of grammatical art, are present in this passage, we omit for the sake of brevity regarding your fabrication, and we shall strive according to the measure of our capacity to examine what you wished to suggest in this most foolish prosecution of yours.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si adoratur crux, adorentur et puellae virgines, quia Virgo peperit Christum.
chunks.english: You say: If the cross is venerated, let young virgins also be venerated, because a virgin gave birth to Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Attendite, obsecro, pietatis et auctoritatis ecclesiasticae sincerissimi cultores et amatores, metaforice et syllogistice loquitur doctor iste, ab inanimali enim faciens transformationem ad animale argumentatur et dicit: Si adoratur crux, adorentur et puellae virgines, eo quod Virgo peperit Christum.
chunks.english: Observe, I beg you, most sincere devotees and lovers of piety and ecclesiastical authority, this teacher speaks metaphorically and syllogistically, for making a transformation from the inanimate to the animate, he argues and says: If the cross is venerated, let young virgins also be venerated, because a virgin gave birth to Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De adoratione quippe et veneratione crucis, quam discrete ob memoriam passionis Dominicae tenendum agendumque sit, beato Gregorius eximius doctor, sicut in superioribus jam dictum est, plenissime docet;
chunks.english: Concerning the veneration and honor of the cross, how it should be prudently maintained and practiced in memory of the Lord's passion, the blessed Gregory, that distinguished teacher, as has already been said above, teaches most fully.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ut autem puellae virgines et praesepia, et veteres panni, et naves, et agni, et leones, et petrae, et spinae ruborum, et arundines, et lanceae adorentur, nemo doctorum, nisi furiosus et mente captus, Claudius solus docet.
chunks.english: But that young virgins and mangers and old cloths and boats and lambs and lions and rocks and thorns of brambles and reeds and lances should be venerated—no teacher, unless mad and deranged in mind, teaches this. Claudius alone teaches it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter ubi secus quam beatus Gregorius Claudius iste de cruce dicit, ab omnibus catholicae et apostolicae Ecclesiae filiis omnino beatus Gregorius, non Claudius sequendus est.
chunks.english: Therefore, where this Claudius speaks otherwise than blessed Gregory about the cross, blessed Gregory, not Claudius, must be followed by all the sons of the catholic and apostolic Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nova vero et inepta quae solus persequitur adoranda, cum eo modis omnibus non solum sunt rejicienda, verum etiam detestanda.
chunks.english: The novel and foolish things that he alone pursues as worthy of veneration must not only be rejected in every way along with him, but also detested.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In hoc sane libello brevitati studentes, tuam, o Claudi, absurdissimam doctrinam de crucis et asini adoratione, quam syllogistica declamatione aeque fieri docuisti, refellendam statuimus.
chunks.english: In this brief work, pursuing brevity, we have determined to refute your most absurd doctrine, Claudius, concerning the veneration of the cross and the donkey, which you taught should be done equally by syllogistic argumentation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caetera vero quae ad injuriam crucis adorandae scripsisti, in sequenti libello commodius improbanda decernimus.
chunks.english: The other things that you have written to insult the veneration of the cross, we decide to refute more conveniently in the following book.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Est praeterea stupendum et admiratione dignum, imo novum et inauditum, et (ut verius inquam) cachinnis puerorum aptissimum, hujusmodi adorationis documentum.
chunks.english: Moreover, this teaching about such veneration is astonishing and worthy of wonder—indeed novel and unheard of, and, to speak more truly, most suitable for the laughter of children.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Forte enim eidem adorationi, crucis videlicet et asini, alias naenias adorandas subtexuisti, ut si in memorata adoratione contemptui et abominationi habereris, sicuti et haberis facilius ad eas adorandas auditores tuos provocano valens.
chunks.english: For perhaps you have woven in other trifles to be venerated alongside this same veneration—namely of the cross and the donkey—so that if you were held in contempt and abomination regarding the aforementioned veneration, as indeed you are, you might more easily provoke your listeners to venerate these others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ais itaque, Si adoratur crux, adorentur et asini, illico reddis causam eo quod asello sedens Dominus Jerusalem usque pervenerit.
chunks.english: You say therefore: If the cross is venerated, let donkeys also be venerated. You immediately give the reason: because the Lord, seated on a donkey, came all the way to Jerusalem.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo asinos adorandos proponis, necesse est ut tales nobis quaeras quales adorari deceat; scis enim quia Italici et Germanici male sunt auriti et ob deformitatem et exiguitatem corporis non merentur adorari.
chunks.english: Since therefore you propose that donkeys should be venerated, you must find for us the kind that are fitting to be venerated. For you know that Italian and German donkeys have ugly ears and because of the deformity and smallness of their bodies do not deserve to be venerated.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Manifestum est autem quia regionis tuae asini magnorum sunt corporum, magnarumque aurium, suaque pulchritudine in se oculos intuentium spectabiliter convertunt.
chunks.english: But it is obvious that the donkeys of your region have large bodies and large ears, and by their beauty they remarkably draw to themselves the eyes of those who behold them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur adorandos asinos praedicas, ex his duos ad instar Jeroboam regis idololatrae assume, quatenus sicut ille ut populum Dei a cultu divino averteret, duos vitulos aureos fabricans unum in Dan, alterum constituit in Bethel (III Reg. XII): ita quoque tu illius exemplo plebem Christi a traditionibus ecclesiasticis avertens, duos, ut dictum est, asinos adorandos eis eligas, quorum alterum in urbe Taurinensi, quem Italia; alterum vero in aliqua civitatum Galliae, quem non solum eadem Gallia, sed et Germania supplex adoret, constituas.
chunks.english: Since therefore you preach that donkeys should be venerated, take two of them after the manner of Jeroboam, that idolatrous king. Just as he, in order to turn the people of God away from divine worship, made two golden calves and set one in Dan and the other in Bethel, as we read in the third book of Kings, chapter twelve, so also you, following his example and turning the people of Christ away from ecclesiastical traditions, should choose for them two donkeys to be venerated, as has been said. Place one in the city of Turin for Italy to venerate, and the other in some city of Gaul for not only Gaul but also Germany to venerate humbly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: O detestanda et abominanda praedicatio, o inconcinna et absona crucis et asini comparatio!
chunks.english: O detestable and abominable preaching! O inappropriate and absurd comparison of the cross and the donkey!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae te, o Claudi, dementia cepit, ut ad tam vesana tamque cunctis catholicis exsecranda scribendo et praedicando proruperis?
chunks.english: What madness has seized you, Claudius, that you have burst forth in writing and preaching things so insane and so execrable to all Catholics?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apostolus quippe non in asino, sed in cruce gloriatur, dicens: Mihi autem absit gloriari, nisi in cruce Domini nostri Jesu Christi, per quem mihi mundus crucifixus est, ego mundo (Gal. VI), et caetera quae de cruce in ejusdem apostoli reperiuntur verbis.
chunks.english: The Apostle indeed glories not in a donkey but in the cross, saying in Paul's letter to the Galatians, chapter six: But far be it from me to glory except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world—and the other things that are found about the cross in the words of this same apostle.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et tu ex obliquo eidem apostolo resultans, quid videris dicere in eo quod ais: Si adoretur crux, adoretur et asinus, nisi ut si quis glorietur in cruce, aeque glorietur in asino?
chunks.english: And you, rebounding obliquely against this same apostle, what do you seem to be saying when you declare: If the cross is venerated, let the donkey also be venerated—if not that whoever glories in the cross should equally glory in a donkey?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videre itaque mihi videor te in scena tergore aselli adopertum quaquaversum pueriliter agitari, multisque te undique circumsepientibus, imo contuentibus, esse miraculo, secumque mutuo de te digitulo protento sermocinari: Ecce homo qui cum in honore positus esset episcopali, non intellexit, ac per hoc asino comparatus, similis factus est illi (Sal. XLVIII).
chunks.english: And so I seem to see you on stage, covered with a donkey's hide, being driven about in every direction like a child, and being a spectacle to many surrounding you on all sides—indeed watching you—and conversing with each other about you with finger pointed: Behold the man who, though he was placed in episcopal honor, did not understand, and therefore, compared to a donkey, he became like it, as the Psalm forty-eight says.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Non enim, o Claudi, putaris absque alicujus certa ratione mysterii asinum adorandum proposuisse, et in eo ita ut in cruce gloriandum predicasse.
chunks.english: For you must not think, Claudius, that without some definite mystical reason you proposed that the donkey should be venerated, and preached that one should glory in it just as in the cross.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia profecto in adoratione asini quam docuisti magnam stultitiae notam acquisisti. Asinus quippe stultum significat hominem, juxta illud Deuteronomii: Non arabis in bove simul et in asino (Deut. XXII), id est, stultum in praedicatione sapienti ne socies.
chunks.english: For indeed in the veneration of the donkey that you taught, you have acquired a great mark of foolishness. The donkey signifies a foolish man, according to that verse in Deuteronomy, chapter twenty-two: You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey together—that is, do not join the foolish with the wise in preaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum cum de asino aeque ut crucem adorando in praesenti libello tuis ineptiis utcunque sit obviatum, breviterque et in sequenti, Domino in cujus manu sumus nos et sermones nobis tribuente, de eadem, crucis videlicet et asini, hinc venienti adoratione, et aliis insensatis rebus quas insensata mente ut crucem adorandas proposuisti, latius prolixiusque sit tractandum;
chunks.english: But since in the present little work we have somehow opposed your foolishness about venerating the donkey equally with the cross—and briefly also in the following work, with the Lord in whose hand we are granting us words—a fuller and more extended treatment must be given concerning this veneration of the cross and the donkey that comes from this source, and concerning the other senseless things that with senseless mind you proposed should be venerated like the cross.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: adhuc tamen conclusionem tuam quam ejusdem rebus secundum tuam doctrinam adorandis subtexuisti, discutiendam statuimus, ubi inquis:
chunks.english: Nevertheless, we have determined to examine your conclusion that you wove in regarding the veneration of these same things according to your doctrine, where you say:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ridiculosa ista omnia sunt, et lugenda potius quam scribenda; cogimurque contra stultos stulta proponere, et contra lapidea corda, non verbi sagittas, vel sententias, sed lapideos projicere ictus.
chunks.english: All these things are ridiculous, and to be lamented rather than written. We are compelled to propose foolish things against the foolish, and against hearts of stone to hurl not arrows of the word or sentences, but blows of stone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum est quod asseris quia ridiculosa sunt omnia et potius lugenda quam scribenda, quae de asini adoratione, et crucis exsecratione, et caeteris quae in reprehensionem ecclesiasticae traditionis alienata mente scriptitasti,
chunks.english: It is true what you assert: that all things are ridiculous and to be lamented rather than written—those things that you have scribbled with alienated mind about the veneration of the donkey, the execration of the cross, and the other matters you wrote in condemnation of ecclesiastical tradition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: cogimurque contra stultitiam tuam talia scribere, tibique, utentes verbis Salomonis (Prov. XXVI), juxta stultitiam tuam, ne tibi sapiens esse videaris, respondere,
chunks.english: We are compelled to write such things against your foolishness, and to answer you according to your folly, using the words of Solomon in Proverbs, chapter twenty-six, lest you seem wise in your own eyes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: et ad penetrandum atque confodiendum lapideum cor tuum, et ad subruendum erroris tui dogma perversissimum, divini verbi sagittas acutas eligere, sanctorumque Patrum sententias congerere, hisque, ut pote siliceis ictibus, os tuum blasphemum oppilando conterere.
chunks.english: And to pierce and stab your heart of stone, and to overthrow the most perverse doctrine of your error, we must choose sharp arrows of the divine word, gather the judgments of the holy Fathers, and with these, as with blows of flint, stop up and crush your blasphemous mouth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Patenter ergo tua propria tela quae in nos jaculari nisus es, viriliter in te vibrando, versa vice retorquemus, et his ut David superbissimum Goliath te tuo lethifero dogmate trucidamus.
chunks.english: Therefore openly we hurl back at you with manly force your own weapons that you tried to throw at us, turning them around, and with these, like David against the most proud Goliath, we slay you with your own deadly doctrine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rursum profetico ex parte abutens alloquio, ita inquis: Redite praevaricatores ad cor (Is. XLVI), qui recessistis a veritate, et diligitis vanitatem, et estis vani facti.
chunks.english: Again, partly abusing prophetic speech, you say: Return to your heart, you transgressors, from the prophet Isaiah, chapter forty-six, you who have departed from the truth and love vanity and have become vain.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et illico apostoli Pauli scribentis ad Hebraeos subnectis documentum, ita subinferens: Qui rursum crucifigitis Filium Dei, et ostentui habetis (Ebr. VI).
chunks.english: And immediately you add the teaching of the apostle Paul writing to the Hebrews, inserting this: You who crucify again the Son of God and hold him up to contempt, from the letter to the Hebrews, chapter six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deinde quia non alienis, sed tuis propriis uteris verbis, inertem atque imcompositam dictionem subinfers, ita subnectens:
chunks.english: Then, because you are using not others' words but your own, you insert an inert and unpolished expression, adding this:

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et per hoc catervatim animas miserorum socias factas daemonum habetis, alienando eas per nefanda sacrilegia simulacrorum a creatore suo, habetis eas dejectas et projectas in damnationem perpetuam.
chunks.english: And through this you keep the souls of the wretched made companions of demons in droves, alienating them from their creator through the unspeakable sacrileges of images. You keep them cast down and thrown into perpetual damnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ubicunque in opusculo tuo quod discutimus alienis uteris verbis, constructio dictionis litterariam vim quam a conditore suo accepit, retinet; sensum tamen proprium, ut pote cauponis pravitate corrotto, heu, proh dolor! amittit:
chunks.english: Wherever in your little work that we are examining you use others' words, the construction of the expression retains the literary force that it received from its author. However, the proper meaning—corrupted, alas, by the depravity of a tavern keeper—is lost.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quoniam non eo modo quo posita, vel eo sensu quo dicta vel intellecta sunt, a te ponuntur vel intelliguntur.
chunks.english: For they are not used or understood by you in the way they were set forth, or with the meaning in which they were spoken or understood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ubicunque vero tuis propriis verbis aliquam niteris construere dictionem, quia litura artis grammaticae, quam contemptui habere diceris, non levigatur, quam fragilis sit quamque ruinae vicina illico agnoscitur.
chunks.english: But wherever you try to construct some expression with your own words, because it is not smoothed by the polish of grammatical art, which you are said to hold in contempt, how fragile it is and how close to ruin is immediately recognized.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Merito quippe absque paleis linitur ruina, et olim a propheta praedicitur (Ez. XIII).
chunks.english: For deservedly the ruin is plastered without straw, as was long ago predicted by the prophet in Ezekiel, chapter thirteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verum, quanquam locutionis ignarus, quia assiduitate tamen lectionis admodum detritus es, divinorum eloquiorum paginas, et non solum sanctorum Patrum, verum etiam gentilium philosophorum accurata dicta enucleatim scrutare,
chunks.english: But although you are ignorant of speech, because nevertheless you are thoroughly worn down by constant reading, you carefully examine the pages of divine eloquence and not only of the holy Fathers but also the precise sayings of pagan philosophers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: et nequaquam in eis constructionum tuarum exempla valebis reperire. Unde magnae admirationi haberis, et cum recte loqui nescias, te quoque nescire non intelligas, nec tacere stultitia impellente queas, secundum prudentissimi viri consilium: Stultus si tacuerit, sapiens reputabitur; et si compresserit labia sua, intelligens (Prov. XVII).
chunks.english: Yet in no way will you be able to find in them examples of your constructions. Hence you are held in great wonder, and though you do not know how to speak correctly, you do not understand that you do not know, nor can you keep silent since foolishness drives you on, contrary to the counsel of the wisest man: If a fool keeps silent, he will be considered wise; and if he presses his lips together, he will be thought intelligent, from Proverbs, chapter seventeen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quapropter necesse est ut tibi prospicias, et ab hujuscemodi constructionibus, quibus extraordinarie uteris, te cohibeas; scilicet ut ea quae non didicisti non doceas, et libros condere nequaquam praesumas,
chunks.english: Therefore it is necessary that you look out for yourself and restrain yourself from such constructions as you use extraordinarily—that is, that you not teach what you have not learned, and not presume to compose books.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quoniam cum in manus peritorum devenerint, minime morsu reprehensionis ac vituperationis carebunt.
chunks.english: For when they come into the hands of the learned, they will by no means be free from the bite of censure and reproach.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recurramus igitur ad id quod intulisti, ubi cum Propheta ais: Redite praevaricatores ad cor. (Is. XLVI).
chunks.english: Let us return therefore to what you brought forward, where you say with the Prophet: Return to your heart, you transgressors, from Isaiah, chapter forty-six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepissime namque Dominus hunc sermonem per Prophetam inculcat et replicat, meritoque populum suum praevaricatorem appellat, eo quod a cultu legis divinae aversus, ad idolà se convertit, eumque, ut ad cor redeat, admonet, scilicet, ut relicta idololatriae superstitione, ad Deum ex toto corde redeat.
chunks.english: For the Lord very often presses and repeats this message through the Prophet, and deservedly calls his people transgressors because, turning away from the worship of divine law, they turned to idols. And he admonishes them to return to their heart—that is, leaving behind the superstition of idolatry, to return to God with their whole heart.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quomodo autem hic sermo propheticus nobis fidem catholicam et apostolicam inconcusse tenentibus, traditionalesque ecclesiasticas, quas a sanctis Patribus accepimus, incorrupte servantibus conveniat, cum nullis indiciis nullisque documentis approvare valeas,
chunks.english: But how this prophetic saying applies to us who unshakably hold the catholic and apostolic faith and incorruptly preserve the ecclesiastical traditions that we received from the holy Fathers, you cannot prove with any evidence or any arguments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: restat profecto ut non nos, sed te potius praevaricatorem, qui statuta ecclesiastica ausu temerario convellere conaris, intelligas; et ad cor, id est, ad sensum ecclesiasticae tradizionei congruentem quantocius redire festines,
chunks.english: It remains therefore that you should understand not us but rather yourself as the transgressor, you who attempt with reckless boldness to overthrow ecclesiastical statutes. And you should hasten to return as quickly as possible to your heart—that is, to a sense in harmony with ecclesiastical tradition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sciens quoniam impune non cedet omni ab eo aliorsum peregrinanti, et cum extraneo fornicanti.
chunks.english: Know that it will not go unpunished for anyone who wanders away from it elsewhere and commits fornication with a stranger.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod agens, probabis non nos, sicut scripsisti, sed te magis a veritate recedere, et vanitatem diligere, et vanum factum esse, sicut tua inepta scripta dimostrant.
chunks.english: By doing this, you will prove that it is not we, as you wrote, but rather you who depart from the truth, love vanity, and have become vain, as your foolish writings demonstrate.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Repetamus etiam apostolicum sermonem, quem ut tuum proprium posuisti, quo ais: Qui rursum crucifigitis filium Dei et ostentui habetis (Ebr. VI).
chunks.english: Let us also take up again the apostolic saying that you put forward as your own, where you say: You who crucify again the Son of God and hold him up to contempt, from the letter to the Hebrews, chapter six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Idcirco enim nos apostolico sermone percellere putatis, rursumque crucifigere Filium Dei, et ostentui habere calumniatis, eo quod ob memoriam passionis Dominicae imaginem crucifixi Christi in auro argentove exprimimus, aut certe in tabulis diversorum colorum fucis depingimus.
chunks.english: For you think to strike us down with apostolic speech, and you falsely accuse us of crucifying the Son of God again and holding him up to contempt, because in memory of the Lord's passion we fashion the image of the crucified Christ in gold or silver, or paint it on panels with pigments of various colors.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod si ita est, quantum a sensu apostolico sensus iste abhorreat, quisquis scrupulosissime praecedentia et sequentia Epistolae ejusdem apostoli legerit, perspicue animadvertet.
chunks.english: But if this is so, whoever reads most carefully what precedes and follows in the letter of this same apostle will clearly perceive how far this interpretation is from the apostolic meaning.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apostolus quippe his qui per gratiam Baptisti semel fuerant illuminati, et caetera quae enumerat sancti Spiritus dona consecuti, haec loquitur.
chunks.english: For the Apostle speaks these things to those who had once been enlightened through the grace of baptism and had received the other gifts of the Holy Spirit that he enumerates.
chunks.notes: The text has 'Baptisti' which appears to be 'Baptismatis' (baptism) corrupted

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ciao namque qui peccata quae post Baptistum admiserant, non nisi Baptistatis iteratione dilui posse putabant, merito ab eodem apostolo arguuntur, eo quod rursus sibimetipsis crucifigerent Filium Dei et ostentui haberent, quod omnino impossibile esse affermat.
chunks.english: For those who thought that the sins they had committed after baptism could not be washed away except by repeating baptism are deservedly rebuked by this same apostle, because they would crucify the Son of God again for themselves and hold him up to contempt, which he declares to be completely impossible.
chunks.notes: The text has 'Baptistum' and 'Baptistatis' which should be 'Baptismum' and 'Baptismatis' (baptism)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille enim qui secundo se baptizari posse putat, rursus Christum (sicut a Patribus traditum accepimus) sibimetipsi crucifigit et ostentum habet.
chunks.english: For he who thinks he can be baptized a second time crucifies Christ again for himself and holds him up to contempt, as we have received by tradition from the Fathers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut igitur impossibile est rursus crucifigi Christum, hoc est, ostentui eum habere, quoniam, ut Apostolus ait: Christus resurgens a mortuis, jam non moritur, mors ei ultra non dominabitur (Rom. VI); ita nimirum impossibile est peccata quae post Battesimo ammettetuntur Battesimo iteratione Purgari.
chunks.english: Therefore, just as it is impossible for Christ to be crucified again—that is, to be held up to contempt, since, as the Apostle says in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter six: Christ rising from the dead dies no more; death no longer has dominion over him—so indeed it is impossible for sins committed after baptism to be purged by repeating baptism.
chunks.notes: The text has 'Battesimo' which should be 'Baptismo' (baptism)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia sicut Christus semel mortuus est carne in cruce, sic et nos semel morimur in battesimato, non carne, sed peccato. Ac per hoc sicut ille rursus crucifigi non potest, ita et nos rursus baptizari nequimus.
chunks.english: For just as Christ died once in the flesh on the cross, so also we die once in baptism, not in the flesh but to sin. And therefore, just as he cannot be crucified again, so we cannot be baptized again.
chunks.notes: The text has 'battesimato' which should be 'baptismato' (baptism)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Peccata porro quae post battesimo committuntur, poenitentiae lacrymis et eleemosynarum largitionibus diluuntur.
chunks.english: Moreover, sins that are committed after baptism are washed away by tears of repentance and generous giving of alms.
chunks.notes: The text has 'battesimo' which should be 'baptismo' (baptism)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur ita tenemus et credimus, nequaquam, ut mendaciter astruis, rursus Filium Dei nobis crucifigimus et ostentui habemus.
chunks.english: Since therefore we hold and believe this, we in no way crucify the Son of God again for ourselves and hold him up to contempt, as you falsely assert.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac per hoc in hac prosecutione tua, sicut et in caeteris, te delirasse evidentibus indiciis declaratur.
chunks.english: And therefore in this argument of yours, as in the others, you are shown by clear evidence to have raved.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Telum vero ridiculosae constructionis tuae, quod ex tuo sensu fabricatus es, quo ais: Et per hoc catervatim animas miserorum socias factas daemonum habetis, alienando eas per nefanda sacrilegia simulacrorum a creatore suo, habetis eas dejectas et projectas in perpetuam damnationem,
chunks.english: But the weapon of your ridiculous construction, which you have fashioned from your own understanding, where you say: And through this you keep the souls of the wretched made companions of demons in droves, alienating them from their creator through the unspeakable sacrileges of images, you keep them cast down and thrown into perpetual damnation—

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: quia in nos frustra jaculatur, jure obtundetur, meritoque in auctoris sui caput exacutum retorquebitur.
chunks.english: because it is hurled at us in vain, it will rightly be blunted and deservedly hurled back sharpened at the head of its author.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dignum namque est ut quia in nobis nihil quod feriret invenit, ad eum a quo frustra directum est, redeat atque confodiat.
chunks.english: For it is fitting that, since it found nothing in us to strike, it should return to him by whom it was sent in vain and pierce him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quoniam non nos animas miserorum socias fecimus daemonum, easque per nefanda sacrilegia simulacrorum a creatore suo avertimus, et in damnationem perpetuam dejecimus:
chunks.english: For it is not we who have made the souls of the wretched companions of demons, turned them away from their creator through unspeakable sacrileges of images, and cast them into perpetual damnation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: sed ille potius daemonibus eas sociavit atque in perpetuam damnationem dejecit, qui corpora sanctorum contemptui haberi, et vexillum crucis abominari, caeterasque ecclesiasticas traditiones contra fas sperni, et asinum eos docuit adorare.
chunks.english: Rather, he has joined them to demons and cast them into perpetual damnation, who taught them to hold the bodies of the saints in contempt, to abominate the banner of the cross, to spurn other ecclesiastical traditions contrary to what is right, and to venerate the donkey.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cogimur aptis congruisque responsionibus vanas et ineptas refellere obbietiones, quod quia per singula prolixitate vitanda in hoc libello facere omittimus, tandem ei hic finem imponimus.
chunks.english: We are compelled to refute vain and foolish objections with fitting and appropriate responses. But since we omit doing this point by point in this little work to avoid prolixity, we finally impose an end on it here.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et ne quippiam tantarum naeniarum indiscussum praeteriisse videamur, ea quae restant, in sequenti libello discutienda distulimus.
chunks.english: And lest we seem to have passed over any of such great trifles without examination, we have deferred to the following book the discussion of what remains.
